reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI really used to like this game. I would, as many did, recommend this game to my friends, telling them that it was really fun and a cool little buildy game. It had a free-to-play aspect, but I was OK with that. I even gave the developers some money and bought some items. I now wish that I had saved my money. This game has, like many of my bots, been flown into the ground at a rapid rate after several of the important bits have been taken away. It used to be that you would build a robot of a certain tier, and would be matched with similar robots. Hearing complaints about how you could exploit the ranking system, they attempted to balance it, but it was a crap method of doing so: by completely removing the system. At this point, I stopped playing for a while. I came back to this game, hearing of a new update, and they had in fact removed features. You didn't need a pilot's seat, armor had been completely...reworked
date:
and they had made glass, which was SUCH A COOL-LOOKING BLOCK, into a freakin' cosmetic item! And the only way to get cosmetic items is with real money. Oh, did I mention that MOST COLORS OF PAINT YOU NEED TO PAY FOR?!
*sigh*

VERDICT:
If Freejam pulls their act together, I would heartily recommend this game. However, in its current state, I would say hold off.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The last major update really dumbed down the game, before you would have to really put some thinking into parts purchase, get better armor cubes? or shields? or guns? one had to play  with th diferent cubes armor rating in order to protect the vital parts of the robot (besides other things).
Now if you just make a bot with a bunch of blocks and strap a bunch of guns and you can survive for ages! Before one could get one shot kill with bombers or  railguns if hit the right robot spot, Now it takes forever to destroy pretty much anyone because everyone uses the same blocks. Block type is one variable removed that helped to make the game challenging.

A bad remark also for the non-compensation on blocks when the update was made, some of us have spent a lot on blocks and that was a waste of time and money for some. I'm glad i didn't spent any money on this game otherwise I would lose the investment in blocks. I don't recomend to spend money on this game because you can lose your items overnight in some crazy update or your item can be rendered useless by an update

Another one is the pilot seat removal, it helps to create diferent shapes of robots, but now you don't have to protect your sweet spot! again, making the game easier by removing the sweet spot and the limitations the pilot seat had.

The worst one is the auto healing, this completly changed the game dynamics! before you had to think on how to build your robot even for the case it would get damaged, making sacrificial parts to be blown when under attack. Also you had to put some extra locomotion parts, in case you would lose wings, wheels, etc. when under attack.
Now you have auto healing! no need for this! just hover your bot over a mountain, if someone shoots you down, just lay on there hidden (when possible) and wait to be up and running again! Same for tanks, just hide in a corner when your health is getting low.
Before the update you would think twice before engaging, now everyone is Kamikaze! before you could damage an airplane or tank useless with a couple of shots, so people would be carefull when atacking, now everyone just charges ahead full steam!

Also untill the introduction of the AA canon, the game was quite unbalanced, air units had a massive advantage because of the hit and run tatic, T10 block and the auto regen.

Only good remark was the introduction of colours.

They added Flak, LOML, and worst of all the Proto Seeker (all three of which are weapons that need no skill at all, since two of them are lock on and the flak has a huge explosion radius). They removed Megabots. And lastly, they added crates and removed RP (which makes it nearly impossible to get the parts that you need).

Robocraft used to be a great game, but now it's ruined.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Dont count my hours on steam, ive got over 1000 on their standalone launcher:

To start off, I really want to reccomend this game, and if the recent blasphemy of a expansion gets chanced, ill consider changing my review to a positive. In the meantime however, FreeJam has done a very good job at completely destroying the game.

First off, my most hated patch: Matchmaking:  match-making takes into account Player Skill, Player Level and CPU of Robot.
While it sounds ok at first, it was stated and ment to be a CPU based system, the bigger your bot you made, the higher matching tier you get into, great for everyone, while the algorithim was bad, it was more or less acceptable. They made player skill and player level a thing now. With this, a max level player now can not play with a low level friend, without their friend getting the shaft, seriously. Play a match with a buddy whos 150 like myself, and the guy is under 40, BY DEFAULT my level puts him into high ranking matches. WTF? Good job on destroying party play.

Progression: NEW PLAYERS READ!
Progressoin used to be fairly straightforward. WIth the introduction of Loot Crates and matchmaking changes, Your going to find yourself in a black hole of stress and anxiety that will only be saited with death and dismemberment. New players will have a starting bot and starting armaments, no extras, no money no nothing. You will be put into matches with players who now have everything, who are capable of oneshotting your little starter mech with the simplest of weapons, Im warning you now, if you DO decide to play, Understand that you will die, countless countless times as you level. I almost reccomend you buying a humble bundle code for 6 bucks, it will atleast give you starter material and 90 days of premium. The grind to get gear is RNG based, so finding that wing you need, or that wheel, could take you a long...long time.

Loot Crates: The addition of Loot crates this new expansion was good in theory, the game orriginally allowed you to purchase items with the money made each match, allowing players to build how they want. Now? Now you have to open loot crates, a RNG system, that allows you to obtain items from the game on a random basis, items you dont like, you can salvage for 1/20th the value of the item, thats right, 1/20th. Before, you could play a match, and afford a weapon, or perhaps a wing, or maybe a little bit of blocks. Now players, especially new players are unable to build freely. You must break down items you dont want, to get 10-200 robits (currency used in game), then spend 20k+ robits to buy a weapon that would have taken far less time to recieve, OR get lucky and get one in a case.

Combat: Combat was great for a time, then the introduction to Lock on Missle Launchers (LOML henseforth) and Protoseekers (PSK) has created a game that no longer requires accuracy or skill, instead requires a person simply to get a lockon beforeyou. A game with this content, with this gameplay , should NOT contain weapons that allow a player to simply lock on and kill. This effectively nullfies any Flying bots almost indefinatly.

FreeJam Company: They have a bad habbit of being quiet, While i supported them at the start, over the years ive seen them turn their backs on their playerbase 95% of the time, when they are listening to us about imbalances, horrible matchmaking, or bugs/gliches, they put patches out that not only negatively affect the game, but introduce even more issues!

Combined with the issues of Matchmaking, Lock On weaponry, and a company who doesnt listen to the cries of their victums, you have a perfect recipe for disaster that can only be mitigated with a clean house at FJ. They seriously need to hire a better PR manager and hire some more devs who are a little more knowledgable in arena gameplay, the current ones are only worried about expanding content, not fixing problems. Fix your ♥♥♥♥ FreeJam, in 3 days, youve lost almost 8% of your positive votes on steam, for good reason, it took you 3 years to build up respect and only 3 days to destroy it, I hope this is a lesson that you take seriously because your about to lose your entire playerbase in less than a month if you dont revert or fix some of the crap youve done to the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a good game that gets some unfair negative reviews and hate.  I am going to address some unfair attacks at this game.

The BIG thing about these negative steam reviews is that anybody can write them thus many Loser players with idiot tank designs come here to take out their anger on the game’s store page.  This is partly thanks to the chat window in the games main lobby where countless 9 year-olds tell the whole server why they lost because SMG’s are cheap and not because they rushed in alone with their no-armor hovercraft in between 5 enemy tanks.  When other normal players lose to an SMG tank they see the chat and believe the exaggerated comments and join them, then they start venting their anger too. The other slightly more fair reviews I’ve seen are from the old-time players who say the game devs ruined the game. I’m a little newer at this than them and I’ve played almost 40 hours of gameplay in these dark times
date:
made it to T5 and had fun all the way, and there’s no signs of the fun stopping any time soon. The people who are having fun (and there’s a lot of us) don’t bother to write reviews, just the people who want to vent their anger do.

The first thing people say is that this game is pay2win but that just isn’t true. First of all, paying users and free users get all the same parts to work with and second, in this game your robot has a stat for ranking. When you add a part to your robot it raises the rank stat and if you reach a certain point it will go up in tier. There are 10 tiers of robots and you just about always get put against robots in your tier so paying 2-win is impossible. The only thing paying does for you is give you faster progression through the tiers. Some people say its pay to progress but I’m on top of T5 and I haven’t had that problem yet although I think during a certain update it was bad but they have already fixed that by now. Progression isn’t super important anyway because by T5 every TYPE of part is unlocked, just not the bigger stronger versions (which are in there own tier). Unlike World of tanks and other F2Ps you can still make cool stuff at lower tiers and there’s none of that “premium ammo” crud that I hate.

Now for the second big thing to talk about, op (over powered) weapons and parts. Every type of weapon gets called “op” 90 times in the same day because of that venting 9 year-old thing I told you about before. One big thing to keep in mind is that this game is in alpha so balance is subject to change. I hate when people say “plasma has ruined this game forever” because even if plasma was cheap the devs would rebalance it ASAP. There are only 3 different types of weapons in the game (for now) and they all have their intended functions. I’m not saying the game has always had perfect balance (and it still doesn’t) but it’s still a lot of fun to play. The last thing about balance is that a lot of players are new to this game and don’t know what they can do. An example would be that hovercrafts can dodge plasma shells vertically but I don’t see many players do this. Those players could go on to say that plasma is cheap or that hovercrafts are underpowered but the real problem is that the players don’t try new tactics.

People whine a little about other things like lag, warping and glitches but I have never had those problems, those things are just more problems that people unfairly vent out during their rants.

Overall I just wanted to tell you that this is a really fun game that can make you think and adapt, and also that the devs aren’t evil (I think), they gave us free stuff as makeup for a server crash they had. If the game gets big and devs finish this right then this could be a really great and solid game. Thanks for reading, PEACE OUT!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I used to play Robocraft since the beginning. It was a simple game with hidden complex gameplay mechanics. When you started, you build a robot with a gun and played some games. That said, building is quite simple and intuitive. You don't have to be an engineer to build a working robot. But the more you played, the more you understood the little weaknesses of your robot. Also you had to improve your skill with the available weapon. Especially your aiming and prediction was very important (like in other Shooters ofc). What made this game also great is how Freejam handled the pricing of products. A monthly premium membership, which doubled your loot after a battle (currency to buy new robot parts) only cost 5$ per month, which is very fair compared to other games, who charge 10$+ for monthly membership. And even without premium you could easily get all the parts you wanted.

But since the new updates, this all changed... sadly

1. Monthly Premium costs now 10$ for a month. They also introduced loot boxes. If you get a loot box after a game, you get a row with 4 different items (random). And with premium you get a second row with another 4 items. Probablemtic about this is, that you also see the 4 premium items even if you dont have premium. It's a common tactic from mobile games to show the players what they COULD have gotten if they had premium. I dont like these fishing tactics and I'm sad that this is introduced in Robocraft that way...

2. They removed most of the depth from the game. You can now literally built any crap and it's working. They did this to make Art bots possible (example: A robot that looks like a house)

3. They introduced a MOBA-like gamemode. It's quite easy to observe they Freejam tries to implement every trend possible.

4. All new weapons require no skill. In the past, there were railgun (sniper), SMG (automatic weapon) and plasma launcher (grenade launcher). You needed aiming for all these weapon. The new weapons are flak cannon (impossible to dodge as flying unit), rocket launcher with aiming assist (rockets follow players when locked in) and a rapid firing gun with following bullets.

The game becomes more and more casual combined with high prices for premium membership and fishing tactics. I can't support a game like this and it makes me sad that I have to write a negative review after all those hours of playtime...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's been a while since I last played this game and enjoyed it.
Where to start...
I had first heard about this game when my brother and a couple of his friends had been playing it. I started off in the laser-fest that was tier one, and slowly began making my way up the challenging but very fun slope of technology. School starts, and I make two new friends (which are still great friends today) because we all had one thing in common: Robocraft. I got a lot of my other PC gamer friends to join us and we had a blast. The developers were releasing updates fairly frequently, and added my most favorite weapon, the Nanotech Disruptors. The majority of my friends an I were in tier 4-5, and I couldn't wait to get them, since I love playing support. I literally couldn't wait, so I payed $10 to get them and some extra in game money as well. The game kept getting better, and everyone was having a great time. I was in tier 7 right as they added spider legs.

At this point, the game was at its peak.
Not necessarily the peak as in the most enjoyable time, but as in right when it started to go downhill. The updates got more obscure as the game went on, adding in tank treads and other cool new weapons and addons, rebalances etc. However, there was one update that completely crippled this game. What seemed a cool new concept and great way to have fun in the game turned into a huge cluster♥♥♥♥ of people spamming caps in the chat because we weren't defending top lane or that someone kept getting spawnkilled. This was the update that added the new gamemode with the huge mechanical mushroom looking things with gems or whatever the ore was called at the top. I heard about it and was actually decently excited, the game needed a new gamemode. I played about 40 of these matches, and figured out that it was no where near as fun as the risk vs reward of the classic gamemode. Of course, you could sitll play classic, but with this new shiny gamemode about 4 people in each tier were actually playing classic. We (being my friends and I) decided to take a bit of a hiatus from the game, to see how it was doing later in development.

Fast forward half a year or so, I meet a streamer from the Netherlands and a friend at school who have both played recently. The tech tree is essentially gone, all progress has disappeared (including my ten dollars mind you) and they add ♥♥♥♥ing round blocks, to a square based building system. The community gets more toxic, the demographic has completely changed, and was once a life changing game has transformed itself into a monstrous cardboard box of ♥♥♥♥ on my doorstep.

In its earlier stages, I would have reccomended this game. Now? Well, lets just say I'd rather play Bad Ratz for 4 hours straight than play this deformed atrocity for an hour. I'm sad that it had to end this way, and wish it would magically revert to its old state. We miss you, old Robocraft.

Then after work log onto robocraft in your personal downtime for a completely different and highly enjoyable experience.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Do I recommend this game: Hell yes.

I have spent a good deal of the past few months on this game, and I can tell you that  by achieving 1000 hours of gameplay very recently, that this game is not the kind of indie you'd expect. The devs are always checking up on forums, responding to concerns, and helping in every way they possibly can to a several-thousand person player-base, with 15 devs running the place. They've gone to exceedingly long lengths to make this game balanced, and if any player out there gets into this game early, know this: all that fun you're having in the low tiers? Yeah, it only gets better from there :D.

I honestly am extremely proud to say that my favorite game of all time has won indie of the year, and I cannot say it enough, thank you to all the people that make this game fun.

~~RC IS LOVE, RC IS LIFE~~

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Robocraft...........I can only say that it is among the single most fun mmo I have ever played. I have played alot of mmo's and they all suffer from the same thing.....Best Builds. A build or a set of builds that can beat all others in pvp and pve.

Robocraft does not have this. Some builds are better then others in one thing and crappy in another. It is very much up to the player to decide how they want to play and while you can grab a tutorial or buy a bot (the pay to get bots are usually really crappy and serve mostly as a fun cosmetic thing rather than a viable build to play) there is trillions of ways to build a bot. I am almost in tier 10 myself and i have seen planes with wheels or cruisers that can hover. Tanks with legs and so much more.

While there aren't many play modes each battle is different. One battle you will get utterly crushed and the next the timer click to 0 because you were too evenly matched and got a long battle. The variations in bots and tactics make it very fun. The devs are polite kind and helpful. Ususally offering a day of free premium every once in awhile. If the servers crash they work tirelessly to get them back up. They care about the players and seem pretty determined to avoid a pay 2 win model.

But don't take my word for it, go in there and play fr yourself.......be warned though you will probably get addicted to it.

Early Access Review

It breaks my heart to write a bad review for this game. So much time and effort went into building and perfecting bots, talking the game up to friends and co-workers, and just playing the game.

To keep it simple, Robocraft USED to be one of the best titles on steam in my opinion. It had a great player base, was different, and FUN.

But the DEVs are so misguided. They're so afraid to hurt someone's feelings. Every update they release leaves us long time players lost. The new Game mode is garbage it allows players to hide behind a shield that the enemy can't shoot in. Removing the tier system completely broke match making. The new CPU cap made all my fine tuned bots unuseable. THe game is going south quick.

It's almost like Robocraft has had it's left wing shot off while trying to plasma bomb someone and is now in a death spiral with no healer in sight.

For instance, in 2014, you would shoot at a guy and they'd shoot back at you. Simple.
In 2016, you would shoot at a guy and they'd shoot a ROCKET OUT OF THIN AIR and blow you to smitherines, then go behind a rock to regenerate ALL OF THE DAMAGE YOU DID TO THEM.

It's less a game about strategy, more a game about following a formula.

Step 1: Shoot.
Step 2: Hide
Step 3: Regenerate
Step 4: Repeat

Overall, I do like this game, but I don't think I can recommend it to you guys just yet, as it is still in Early Access and has a lot of balancing issues. Devs, if you're reading this, can you PLEASE remove the auto-regen feature? It just means that medics have almost nothing to do, as people just repair themselves.

And for that, I give this game a 7/10

As I said before, it's not a bad game, it's just... flawed. If the devs fix some of the balancing issues, and fix the tech tree (Where did my TX weapons go? I don't have a high enough level? What?") I'll be more than willing to write a more positive review. As for now

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I ve been playing this game on and off for two or three years now and heres what i feel about the game

In the beginning there was creativity.  I would fight other bots that resembled bad ♥♥♥ futuristic tanks, air and ground walkers, and bots that ressembled creations out of movies like star wars or halo

there was balance in chasis cubes.  And i dont mean just the cubes i also mean armor.  You would see decent builds with a little bit of armor for protection and overall have a balanced fight in a match

However ive started to play again for a few matches and i was upest to find some of the keythings that made this game fun...are while not gone, slowly being used less than they originally were

I see more armored turtles with guns poking out in a match then i see a decently built, creative, cool looking battle machine these days and i think that is mostly because armor has gotten far too important in building a robot

Nothing seems to be balanced anymore in terms of creativity and building balance of cubes and its really upsetting because this was and still can be a really fun game to play and i dont want to see it go down the tubes just because the development teams dont do anything to bring the creativity back.

That stuff on the new cover for the game is never seen in a real match.  Because if it were it would be incinerated by hovering builds covered head to toe in armor.

The creativity to make robots is still very much in the game but the matchs themselves make it impossible to win with these creative bots because they get destroyed by these other robots that are covered in parts so high in defense that they shread you to pieces before you can do some damage.

So if the development team(s) ever read this then please do something about balancing out these parts so that it is not impossible to win a game creativly.

And to the people reading this review i say to give robocraft a try, its not a bad game it just can be frustrating at times.  But if you find you' re always getting frustrated and always getting destroyed in matches, then i would reccomend to just  play something else and stay updated on robocraft to see if the dev's fix these problems that have been occuring.
And if you dont feel like waiting then im sorry robocraft has disappointed you

these are just my opinions on the game so please dont harass or synically bash me over the head through the internet because im trying to helpful while still positive for a game i really want to pull through.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

2 years later, this game is still garbage. Not that it was ever that good.


1. They removed the Tier System, the best aspect of the game. They also removed pilot seats so people could make ridiculously unrealistic robot designs with no strategic placing whatsover. The game now places you against superior oppenents with ridiculously overpowered robot designs.

2. Matchmaking is terrible. Wait times are generally over two and a half minutes, and you will get placed with the same people that you played with before (even if there are >4000 people online)

3. New mech types are absolutely unrealistic. Walkers can run as fast as a tank with 4 wheels and a thruster on the back of it. One helicopter blade can support an entire robot if it is on the back of it.

4. Microtransactions everywhere. Pay for premium, cosmetics, robot designs, building materials, you name it. The game is a living advertisement of its own microtransactions. The queue window features robot designs that you can buy with premium currency. It even has a little note that states how much the ingame currency amount is equivelant to in USD, so all the little 10 year olds that buy these stupid and uneeded items can tell their mommies exactly how much money they are wasting on this game.

The only positives about this game is the originality of the concept of the game. However, its 2 years old now, and I think the hype has died down. The updates they made to the game don't make it fun anymore. I wouldn't waste your time.

Hello Players!
I might be a bit biased in this review and no offence to the developers, but the game sucks. I could have given it a positive review a year ago, before the update. Before it was clear (Tiers). People played with people who are the same Tier as them, and the game was more or less balanced. I mean there was at least some balance. Of course there were some super donors who actually bought good stuff and played with you. Even if they killed you, that was fair enough. You cold just face it. And you could see by their blocks, colours and stuff how good they are and whether to evade them or fight them.
The update messed up the game. Now, textures were removed, colours for each Tier block where removed and what? Yo can colour your Mark 10 (Tier 10) blocks white and everybody will attack you. And you just rek them.
Also before GC (Galaxy Cash) had a higher value. You could buy a Megabot for like 5 dollars GC or could build a boog T7 for 10 euros. Like super mega Tier 7 or prebuilt magabot. Now, the cheapest crappest robot costs 30 euros, like a Call Of Duty or GTA V game.
Tier system was messed up. Now worst players play with best players. Da hell? Your like T6 and a wild Megabot appears from somewhere and wrecks you, Lol?
If you think differently comment. Sorry for biased opinion.

Yours,
Anton

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Robocraft is a constantly changing game were starmade and world of tanks feel like they had a child.

Pros:
+You get to build your own vehicle, making your immagination important to gameplay
+Game feels unique and unlike others
+Running requirments are low
+Any design choice can have benifits and drawbacks
+Weapons all feel different
+Many ways to move your design are offered
+Maps feel a bit unique
+No pay to win issues
+Frequent updates

Cons:
-Armour block heavy designs tend to die faster than what you would think (in my opinion)
-SMG's have been nerfed to the point were they dont feel like they can do there old jobs now.
-Some of the game modes feel rather unbalanced
-Medics determine the out come of matches a little too heavily (outdated)
-Game balance seams to change faster than you can adapt your design at times
-Premium account needed inorder to make rapid progress
-Requires comitment to feel fun, do to frequent game changes

Final thoughts:
This is a good game, don't get me wrong. Its just that there seams to often be a lack of sustaned game balance. One day, something is added and seams to make designs invulnerable, and the very next day, the opposite is true. There is often no middle ground. All that said, I still like this game. The unique and original feel helps here. Overal, this game deserves a 8.5/10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A nice concept, but terribly done. Maybe my opinion is tainted as i began playing long before all those new ''features'' were added, so let me compare the old robocraft to the new robocraft. But first let me say, this game is not bad, but i can't recommend it to you. It's free, so you might try it out, but there are a Lot better choices to try out if you don't have money and compared to those robocraft is just not worth the efford to download it.

Building a robot is certainly as fun as always, probably even more, since new weapons and special abillities were added... playing with it not so much, especially since you barely gain any points to improve your robot any further. I am sorry, but there is no chance i will play for 10 days just to earn enough points for a single weapon. A few months back it was a whole lot easier, thus you could experiment a lot more and have a lot more fun.

Instead now the game feels a lot like labour, instead of a fun game.

And don't even get me started on health regen. How often have i shot someone into pieces, jsut for him to crawl behind cover and  get fully repaired within seconds. Why even focus on sniper or medic anymore? Cover is extremely expoitable, not only with the new health regeneration, but also with the new rocket launchers.
(get behind cover, lock onto target THROUGH A SOLID ROCK, peekaboo and shoot, repeat)

I am not the only one of my friends, others stopped playing, too, as they could not conform with these crappy changes screwing with the progression system and the balancing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Robocraft is actually extremely fun . . . sometimes.
The idea of the game is great, and there are a lot of fun mechanics.  The developers release updates at faster pace than I've seen in almost any game ever, which is sort of a good thing.

Except that so many of their updates seem so poorly thought out or untested.  Don't get me wrong, Robocraft is improving as a game over time, but every update is two steps forward, one step back.  Each update will release cool new features, and completely breaks something else.  The next will fix the previous issue, but break another part of the game.

Currently, the biggest issue is probably the matchmaking.  Your robot can be placed in a match with robots with hugely better parts.  It completely ruins the game to spend hours carefully designing your bot, and months honing your piloting skills, only to have it get wrecked by a box on wheels because the box on wheels has guns that deal twice as much damage.

I regularly get matched with robots that have over 10 times the ranking rating of mine.

Matchmaking is not the only issue either, other issues include:
-  Lack of voice chat, making communication and strategy with the team nearly impossible.
-  Some very, very flawed map design.
-  The medic tools heal faster than most guns can deal damage (unless at short range), which does not make for fun gameplay.
-  The platoon system (which allows you to play with friends) is glitchy and has been for over a year, which is a long time compared to the very frequent updates this game gets.  It is starting to feel like the developers don't care that trying to play with friends can be a huge pain.
-  The main game mode, battle arena, has some weird mechanics that make for a very strange and not very interesting meta-game.
-  Robots take too long to kill, especially in the early game.
-  Respawn times are too short (<10 seconds) early on in a match, although they do reach more reasonable times after a while.
-  Players frequently abandon the game.  To be fair, sometime it's not their fault and their game crashed.  This often makes matches uneven (like a 6 v 8).  The game tries to balance this by reducing the smaller team's respawn times, but reduced respawn times don't help the smaller team, they just make it take longer for them to lose.

If anyone doesn't understand or agree with something I said in this review I can try to explain in more detail.  Some of the issues are hard to explain in simple point form because it's more like a net of complex problems that exacerbate each other.

Despite the long list of issues, Robocraft is very fun when the matchmaking places you in a fair match.  None of the other issues completely ruin a match like the terrible matchmaking can.  This review will remain negative until players are being put into fair fights.
If the matchmaking is fixed (and another game-breaking issue isn't introduced) in the next update and I forget to update this review, message me or leave a comment and I will.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I liked this game.

Then the full spectrum combat update happened.

Now I'm disappointed.

The tiering system gave you a sense of achievement when you managed to get to building a bot out of the next tier of parts. Different types of armor allowing you to put more importance on protecting THE SEAT by surrounding it with better armor in special patterns. But now there's no seat. No tech tree to upgrade how you want. No armor tiers to differentiate between the tough and the high-damage bots, or the higher tier, more expensive bots from those of lower tiers. NO SEAT WHICH WAS THE ENTIRE FOCUS OF HOW YOU BUILT THE BOT. Protecting your bot from damage is no longer top priority when there's no medic. The entire point of the railgun (aiming for the important part, the seat) is screwed. It's just so disappointing, and I don't know how they will be able to reverse this last update, if they ever do.

RIP Robocraft

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I need to retract a recent positive review of this game. This game used to be mediocre and now it is awful. It is as if the designers sat down in a meeting room and made a series of incomprehensible decisions on the premise that the game was too good and needed to be destroyed as soon as possible.

1) The hexagonal tech tree is now completely linear. It is a straight line. It offers no choices anymore.

2) The armor system has been flattened and offers no choices anymore. All chassis cubes are identical now. You have no options for strength or weight tradeoff anymore, other than to just layer on more armor.

3) The autorepair mechanic is completely bogus and serves to further defeat careful and balanced robot design

4) The plasma mortars have been horribly nerfed. Why? They were always slow and hard to aim, and now they are weak on top of that.

It seems as if the latest game mechanics have been selected to dumb down the game and broaden its appeal, but what they have accomplished, instead, is to make it less fun. Then, in addition to that, as if the laser sights on railguns were not already useless enough to the point that your rail shots veer off in seemingly random directions for no discernable reason, the random hitches and pauses in the game further ensure that you will miss continuously until the point of ragequit. Terrible execution. Declining design values.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The last update (EPIC LOOT)  just ruined the game. The previous update was almost perfect. Was one of my favorite games, now possibly not worth the time.

The Good:
- Possibly one of the best build and fight games out there. Lots of possibilities for robot construction.
- Great players. Can be very punishing if you are new. But ultimately good to help you learn.
- You are forced to bring your A-Game. Good bot construction, good strategy, and good teamwork and planning.
- You have to think on your feet, or you'll be spending most of the time waiting to respawn. Cover, position, speed and stealth mean just as much as skill, bot construction and weapons loadout.


The Bad:
- All weapon, movement and special blocks now cost more relative to previous releases.
- Money was removed in exchange for Robits and you accumulate those at a significantly decreased rate.
- Loot relies heavily on RNG and the loot tables are poor at best. They could be tweaked for better gear to improve rewards, but the way they are now, they're very poor.
- New players will struggle to build up an arsenal that will have them competative with endgame players. Ultimately I think this will stifle entry of new players.
- Ranking system and matching system are broken. Players with very low level (low CPU and poor construction) are getting eaten alive in those matches probably resulting in a very bad experience for them.
- The energy mechanic means you'll be shooting less (probably less load on the servers), but it is a lot less satisfying now than just opening up your entire loadout on an enemy and completely decimating them.
- Oh yeah, and with the slow Robit accumulation, good luck forging that Power Booster you now need to run most of your builds.

The Ugly:
- The epic loot" you get is anything but. Most of the loot you get
date: even when you're on a winning streak just maybe a few blocks that you don't need. Once in about maybe 30 games you get a legendary that comes up and even then you need to subscribe to VIP to get that.\n\nUltimately
recommended: spending money on the game isn't worth it at all. You have to put up with the random number generator (RNG) to give you gear. After having bought 12 protonium crates (i had a bit of money left in my account)

Early Access Review

I used to love this game a lot but now with all the updates the game is becoming progressivly worse.

Before the new paint mechanism you could have any colour of block you want but now without premium you are limited to only white, orange, blue, and grey - meaning you have to pay for the ability to have more colours!

Another bad thing is the new epic loot update - It looked good at first but then you realise when you open a case you only get the worse loot at the bottom and you must have premium to get all the loot you earned!

I used to play this game everyday for the last year or so and I am absolutely disgusted with the dev's for being so greedy and turning one of my favourite games into a Pay to Win money machine. I'd rather pay for the game to play it and have no In-App purchases.

Conclusion:
Don't get this game. Unless your willing to put £100 upfront, avoid at all costs. Without paying, you can't make any progress.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A fantastic game for anyone with a creative mind. Build anything you want and throw it into the battlefield with about anything you could not expect to fight.

Maybe a giant darth vader with laser machine guns against a giant flying pirate ship? Yup it happened.

The game does however require a huge amount of grinding to unlock new types of blocks to build your robots with, which willl take a lot of time to acquire.

Pro:
- Do anything with anything! Very few limits
- Tons of different types of weapons & blocks to try out
- Active devs with tons of big updates

Con:
- Grind, grind and some more grind
- Balancing, getting hit and killed by one shot from the other side of the map is not very funny
- Expensive premium content (not by any means neccesary to play the game, but it is quite expensive anyway)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Stay away from this game, it is not newbie friendly, it is not vet friendly. As a new player you face nothing but seal clubbing, as a vet you face huge sweeping changes that invalidate your thousands of hours. Hell, if you joined this game a month ago and got just a hundred hours in, all that time got invalidated, they practically hit the reset all accounts button.

To preface this: currently as of writing the devs of this game have added crates that you pay for by the bunch that randomly unlock parts, in these crates you mostly get worthless items such as building blocks, and once in a great great great while do you get anything worthwhile. After opening about 100 crates from matches (You get one per match) I got roughly 1 max tier item, about 3 rare items, and the rest were common items (blocks). You can sell things for about 10% of what you have to build them for, so if you want one gun of a different tier, you have to sell 10 guns of another type (aka 10 max tier smgs = 1 plasma gun), but to get these drops is nearly impossible without thousands of crates, WITH PREIMUM.

In the previous patch all parts were insanely expensive, so you had to keep a small inventory while making a bunch of frames made out of blocks while swapping around parts which grows tedious. The devs tried to get people to get so ♥♥♥♥♥♥ at farming forever for a single gun, they simply spend money on the gun. That didn’t work, and only generated animosity.

This game is now going down a much darker road of taking advantage of middle aged people, and younger children with access to parental money (the two groups most likely to suffer from gambling additions). That second group has lost a lot of staying power over the years, but the first one has grown much more common and plays this game much more often while gambling constantly. The devs of this game are taking advantage of children and weak willed adults with addictions and children.

They missed the most critical component to this steam game gambling addition; people gamble because they want to spend money in hopes of getting something back of more value then what they spent, Guess what, the parts in game cannot be solid on the market place (yet). It works in TF2 because real money auction, it works in CS:GO for much the same reason, it works in all valve games because of steam's market place. So people wasting tons of money get nothing but parts in return, so it is 100% money lost.

The next obvious step for the devs is to add cosmetic skins, or just add straight up weapons to the steam market place so you can buy power instantly. This review is going to call it first, you heard it here first folks they WILL do this.

The devs of this game routinely ignore their player base no matter how many people say the same thing and desire the same change, no matter how well you word things, no matter how well you write, or even if your suggestion is amazing. They could implement tiny changes with huge results. They ignore the high-impact low-hanging fruit constantly in favor of implementing wild huge game changing updates. Most recently gaming crates mixed with “you get the same chance reward at all levels” and match making worse than it’s ever been: Robots are purely matched by how many points they cost. Guess what that translates into, vets of the game making extremely efficient, extremely small low-cost robots to get placed into matches with new players that barely understand how the game works.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Uh
Not too sure what to write here so heres a recipe for Pancakes instead

Ingredients:
1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour
3 tablespoons sugar
1 tablespoon baking powder
1/4 teaspoon salt
1/8 teaspoon freshly ground nutmeg
2 large eggs, at room temperature
1 1/4 cups milk, at room temperature
1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract
3 tablespoons unsalted butter, plus more as needed

Now to make it
1. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, baking powder, salt, and nutmeg.
2. In another bowl, beat the eggs and then whisk in the milk and vanilla.
3. Melt the butter in a large cast iron skillet or griddle over medium heat.
4. Whisk the butter into the milk mixture. Add the wet ingredients to the flour mixture, and whisk until a thick batter is just formed
5. Keeping the skillet at medium heat, ladle about 1/4 cup of the batter onto the skillet, to make a pancake. Make 1 or 2 more pancakes, taking care to keep them evenly spaced apart. Cook, until bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, and the undersides are golden brown, about 2 minutes. Flip with a spatula and cook about 1 minute more on the second side. Serve immediately or transfer to a platter and cover loosely with foil to keep warm. Repeat with the remaining batter, adding more butter to the skillet as needed.
6. Procedure for adding fruit to pancakes: Once the bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, scatter the surface with sliced or diced fruit, or chocolate chips, nuts, etc. Flip with a spatula and cook for 1 minute more, being careful not to burn toppings.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nBiggest piece of ♥♥♥♥. Literally, one of the worst as of current. It was great, when it released. It was fun, fair, and was easy enough to progress through the game. And it got better, and better, more ways to move, more weapons, more balancing. Then, things went south. And hard. There was a once upon a time where you literally couldn't fight your vehicle, unless every single block and weapon was of the exact same tier. This made artistic bots, or just bots people were slowly upgrading impossible to play. Then they removed it, so, good, right? Not really. Skip a load of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, and you come to today. Where all blocks are the exact same, and after the update, if you had thousands of high-level blocks, that, from where I stopped, at tier 7, cost around 50k per block, and that's not even tier 10 or mega blocks, you get NO compensation for it. You got your blocks, but guess what? There are all the exact same and you get nothing for the amount of time and money you spent on them. Garage slots are now free, and you got your premium currency back, but it's not enough. They added a paint gun, which is cool, right? Paint all your vehicles nicely. Uh, no. You get 4 colors and need premium for 12 more colors. You get white, blue, orange, and grey. Not a lot. So to sum it up. Even for free, don't download. Get minecraft and get mods. Tons more fun.

Early Access Review

After clocking up 135 hours and greatly enjoying it, my opinion has swayed over the past few months. Changes which break builds, tactics and so on and force you to learn, I expect but not to the extent and frequency to which updates have been released, infact, I enjoy it! The need to learn and develop new skills and builds is good, previous exploits fixed, broken builds, tactics, bugs and so on, fixed and balanced.

Now however, the motivation to go back has completely dwindled now as each update for a good while has reaped the same problems over and over. No longer do I hear about good matches, interesting builds or tactics but rather cheap builds which really shouldn't work at all like rectangles covered in boosters. I understand the game is early access and aspects of it can change drastically but over the past few months updates have been changing the game over and over in such a drastic and reckless manner and too frequently. It seems if people complain enough about how Snipers are OP" and how they get slaughtered when an SMG gets close then an update will mess up the statistics of those builds

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Used to be fun and innovative in the beginning but now every update is taking increasingly big steps towards a bad pay-to-win scenario.
Under these conditions I can't recommend it any more.

I played Robocraft since the very early alpha version in april - quite some time before it came to steam and followed the developement process ever since.
Even though you can get the same stuff by buying it or unlocking it only by playing, several updates made it more and more tedious to unlock parts and grind for credits to buy them.
In contrast by paying real money, you can have them instantly.
Since this does give you a significant advantage and matches are not only fought within the same tiers this is one of many possible ways, pay2win can manifest.

If it was just a quicker unlock I would not even mind too much - that's how it was from the very beginning but the change that ruined it for me the most is that robots now have to get repaired after every fight with ingame or bought credits. You can run bankrupt and end up having to choose between starting all over on a low tier, selling all your parts for 1/3rd of the original price, spending a lot of time designing a new robot from scratch and grinding for credits or just buying the credits for cash.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game itself is actually real fun, there are good-looking items, an interesting game concept and pretty much endless possibilities of building and customizing your own robot. There is nothing bad about that part,
but there seem to be some serious issues to me, such as the reward and balancing system:
I barely get any XP or RP (currency) from successful runs (= double reward), even when healing megabots about 7000 HP, it's not even getting anywhere near 1/10 of my current level.
The other problem is really overweighing the previous one though, having a rank 7000 robot, I'm being put together with others whose robots are way stronger, such as some people with Rocket Launchers, of which one alone got a ranking of 15000, having at least twice of my ranking. Thus about 90% of all my runs are having me face op enemies which can easily take me out with overleveled items, resulting in being killed and removing all fun from the game most of the time.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI had 170 plus hours invested as well as a good amount of money, the initial launch and subsequent updates were very promising and fun giving the player the freedom to craft and fight their own robot against others or on teams while the actual playable arenas only numbered about four these enviroments could be exploited in diferent ways depending on your playstyle .The weapon selection as well as armor and accesories were also promising...and thats were it stopped. The subsequent updates became more about revenue generation than a game that was balanced and fun the last update the loot update was the last in a series of disapointments, as the name says the loot update made victory or defeat rewarded with random pieces for your robot...before this they could be perchased either with player perchased in game money or with coin earned while playing ...however the new update makes it nearly imposible for new players to advance the ranks and turns the beginning matchmaking into a killing field whereapon a later tier player can make a small bot with a powerful gun and unleash carnage upon newer players.(I should know i average 3 kills a match but in this fashion scored an average of 25) I still recommend folks play this game even in its current state I believe has the promise that made me enjoy it from it's start, but as for me it's no longer something I am willing to invest my limited time or money in..no for me it's on to playing Factorio a mod supported minrcraft esk overhead industrial builder that also shows great promise.

Early Access Review

I played this game a year and a half ago, and I didn't like it as a personal preference. Recently, I started playing it again and it was awesome. I enjoyed it a lot and it was one of my favourite games. Unfortunatly, a recent update (epic loot) completly destroyed my enjoyment for the game. First of all, they reset the GC which means all of the real money you spent on it, you don't get back AND you don't get refunds. So if you spent over £100 on this game, that's completely gone. Also, they removed RP and replaced it with this dust thingy which you don't get from finishing games, but ONLY from selling cubes.

EDIT:
Although I have only mentioned negative points above, there is one good thing: crates. I think the idea of crates was a good idea but you should get dust from finishing each game too.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Welcome to the ♥♥♥♥-up that is Robocraft.

So basically there's no reason to play anymore. Too many things that made the game awesome have been removed,  and too many things that absolutely suck have been added. It's just not worth playing anymore. Here are some reasons to stay away:

- Say goodbye to originality as you'll often see many of the same overpowered designs in battles due to the Community Robot Factory. Your original designs that aren't based on exploits won't stand a chance.
- The map variety sucks. Different colours basically. No water-only maps. No air-only maps. No cave maps. Nothing interesting at all. No destructible terrain, no interactivity. Just impenetrable generic hills and walls. For every map.
- Game modes are too same-y. Drive around and shoot. No race mode. No football/other sports mode. Nothing interesting. Same thing over and over. The developers have no imagination or creativity.
- Player base sucks. Too many casuals who copy each other's designs. Too many Japanese cartoon bots. Too many exploiters. Chat is always filled with nonsense.
- Graphics are terrible and unoptimised, not to mention boring.
- Developers don't seem to test or even think new features are actually any good before adding them to the game.
- Sound is very basic and unimpressive. Boring.
- Barely any social options(which I don't mind, personally).

Well damn I'm sure others can elaborate on what's wrong with the game but I just can't be bothered anymore. As of this review, reviews in the last 30 days are 39% positive. They speak for themselves. Stay far away and don't even bother unless the developers get their ♥♥♥♥ together for once. They can never seem to make up their mind. They simply don't have vision.

After the Update i was greeted with a Crate to start. I let the false shine of the Update blind me ,
until i started my first new update game.
i was starting like in old days with my helicopter.
to this time i could only afford one Proto Seeker and always had 2-4 Kills per round.
It ended with me having one assist and 9 Deaths(Note: this was a Battle arena game).
the new ranking system appeareantly brought me in a room full of People who were waay better equipped than i was.

After the round, i was almost mockingly greeted by a crate that looked like it was pulled out of the Trash.

I had few more team death matches and then i did some Research on the new update.
In fact the Review Page was LITTERALY overflowing with bad reviews and i can (sadly)
say that these peole are right, and this update in particular was only created to take the money out of my pocket for cases that arent even worth buying.

My final conclusion is that Robocraft was radically turned ino a Case opening simulator like CS:GO and that the only good thing to say about this update is that it motivates F2P Gamers like me to play other games.

I recommend you guys from Freejam, that you reverse the complete update.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Alright, now I'm ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off.

After sticking with this game for 2 damned years, the devs finally reveal to us that robocraft was destined to be a random, empty, cheap and chaotic cash-grab.

It started out as a tactical, TEAM-BASED, game that made you modify your bot as you played, slowly upgrading and fine tuning your creation till it reached the performance you sought. There was a grind but getting to max teir was awsome, pushing your bot to the limit just enough to get into the next teir was an achievment. There was something to fight for.

Now this mess is comparable to mobile games, every aspect of the game is random, skill means nothing, building even less so. There is nothing to achieve, nothing to strive for, nothing to make you want to log back in as everything has been flattened out. Everything is predictable,

I do not recommend even watching this trash, this 'game' is a shining example of what happens when developers ignore thier following. They've gone out of thier way to completely replace thier fan base and are constantly trying to reinvent what has already been mastered. They add in major content only to rip it out months later. The devs are indecisive, aimless and without a roadplan. They claim that this game is close to beta yet it couldn't ever hope to reach completion.

I've sunk over 1000 hours in this game, never have I been this dissapointed.
This mess started as an ambition and it will end as one.

Sadly, the recent changes to this game have created a system where teamplay, thoughtful design or even attempts at strategic gameplay are heavily penalised.

The only way to win is to out-troll the trolls; the second the odds turn against you you may as well give up.

To make matters worse, you no longer can simply grind your way to a given type of weapon or robot reliably -- previously you could predict how many games you would have to play at the absolute worst to get something; now it's plain impossible as you can not predict what kind of reward you will get overall.

This game has turned from a free-to-play, competitive shooter that rewarded skill and planning to one that rewards a fat wallet and nothing else.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pros: Nice gameplay - although its very unbalanced at the moment (as of 18.05.2016), eg. One weapon dominates all others and is therefore used by most players. It is heading in the right direction, I hope.

Cons: Economy - Alot of grind is necessary to build one bot. Since patch 'Epic Loot' (28.4.2016) the economy got a massive nerf. Especially in the ability to sell things.

Although the gameplay can be alot of fun at times and alowes much freedom to build and test and perfect your own weapon systems on wheels, it is in the moment (as of 18.05.2016) extremely punishing for people who become so called PRO players.
This is because the reward system doesn't reward player action but instead gives players some sort of lottery tickets which have a chance of a reward.
You have to put in a minimum of 200+ hours to be able to build everything you like.
This game has alot of potential and can become great in the future.

Early Access Review

The game was good like two years ago. Now it's a pay to win, grinding-fest, simple-minded bullet hell.
I played two years ago and I thought it was a pretty good F2P game. Not too p2w, but there is still someway for the devs to make money.
There were only cars, hovercars, and planes.
Fine.
They could've kept the game good, but just add cool things, like the insect legs, or the tank treads.
But these massive changes are completely stupid.
I could go on for hours about how the Robot Tiers being removed, and Robot Rank being added is counterintuitive.
But no, I'll rather say that the game has gone to ♥♥♥♥.
There are P2W Homing Missle Launchers, P2W Anti-Air Cannons, and short range teleporters?!!
What happened?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First impressions:

(optional let's play footage)
http://youtu.be/UiQJ5ZGFJlM
I played Robocraft for just under half an hour until I started having trouble connecting to the server and was no longer able to play. I think it’s probably overloaded because of the popularity.

For an alpha the presentation is pretty good. Main menu area looks good. Sounds alright and has decent menu music.

You pilot pre-made or modified robot vehicles. Or build them from scratch piece by piece. You have a selection of different types of chassis blocks i.e. heavy armour or light, propulsion e.g. (hover or wheels, rear wheel drive or front wheel drive etc.), weapons and so on. You make your robot in any shape or configuration you want. You can make a heavy tank, a gunship with long range or short range weapons. Online matches appear to be a team deathmatch.

The typical players robot isn't very pretty but I think this game has a lot of potential for some really cool designs. And because of the apparently huge amount of customisation a large amount of variety to gameplay.

In the short time that I played I basically thought the game was awesome from the start. I've been avoiding Early Access titles but I would definitely recommend playing this game. What have you got to lose? It is free.

Click here for more let’s play videos =)

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game has had ups eiand downs, twists and turns, but all the while I have been playing. In the beginning, it had one of the best matchmaking systems I have ever seen, taking into account the power of the robot instead of a rank like many other games. Robocraft was unique in being able to do this,  due to their building mechanic. Since then, they have revamped the matchmaking into a slaughterhouse, added incredibly overpowered endgame weapons for one team and base weapons for the other, and have turned the game into a near complete pay/grind to win system. I loved this game and it's combat and building used to be unbeatable, but every match is now a roll of the dice between whether or not you are on the team with the smurfs. The latest update has been the worst by far, turning paid for items and worked for items into  a fraction of their original worth and forced the pay to win feature even father down it's users throats. I hope the developers work to return Robocraft to it's original glory. Until then this is me, leaving a negative review, on a game that I have almost 200 hours in.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIn light of all the negativity going around with regards to recent changes to this game, I've been hesitant to write my own critical review for fear of being influenced by the negativity of others. However, recently Freejam released a State of the Game article, which you can read on robocraftgame.com. This article, which I had hoped would be used as an opportunity for the devs to adress the major concerns myself and a large portion of this community have with the most recent major update to Robocraft, instead comes off as an attempt to move the community forward and distract players from the flaws with the current game. Admitidly it does adress the problems players have been having with matchmaking, but it doesn't offer many if any concrete solutions to the very specific problems which many have been pointing out in the weeks since the Epic Loot update, especially with regards to the in game economy and progression system. In light of this, I see no signs of this game deviating from it's present course heading straight for a cliff, and as such do not recommend it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Full disclosure: I started playing after the epic loot update. This game is fun for a while when you first begin, the fun of designing your own robot and sending it to battle is enough for a while but then once you get to around level 50 you realise that there is actually no progression apart from CPU limit. The drops are completely random so you can be level 10 and pick up a 'Rail Erazer' from a purple chest when you come in first place, which is what happened to me. I then dominated every game for another 10-15 levels because my weapon was so much stronger than what anyone had for a while.

The RNG element needs to be toned down, especially since only the person in first place of the winning team will get a purple chest which offers the only semi-worthwhile loot. Its like a feedback loot, the people who keep coming first place will get the best loot and then they will keep winning and having a higher chance of getting the better loot. See where I'm going?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After having played this game for a lot of hours, many more before it was linked to steam, which probably gets my total time to well over 1000 hours, this last update has killed the game for me.

I had a blast in this game, but the developers seemed to have lost their focus and are no longer able to deliver what they promised.
What drew me to this game was the ability to build your own bot and then use it to fight.
Fight outcome was determined by the team that had the best BUILD bots, thus rewarding creativity of players, well build bots performed better then sloppy build bots.
However, the last few patches killed all of this, increasing damage done by weapons and lowering armor values of building blocks, which resulted in any bot being able to kill any bot, regardless of how well it is build.
Also the implementation of the shop where people can sell their bots, that killed creativity even more.

The motto of this game is build, drive, fight. It should be changed, cause with the new loot system, you have no freedom of building anymore, thus limiting creativity. People are heavily encouraged to buy a bot on the shop, discouraging creativity even more.

Lastly, the most recent weapon rebalance has left the gameplay incredibly stale, which is the reason I finally decided to stop playing this game. If they would have bothered to fix at least some of the issues the game has at its core, like matchmaking in the ranked matches, I could have looked past a lot of all of the above, but alas, making shiny crates seems more important that fixing the real issues here, which sums up pretty much all the issues this game has and it doesnt seem like that will change anytime soon.

I joined the game several years ago, back then, it was simple, time consuming but fun. a while ago you added things like tank tracks, heli blades, etc. i was amazed, it was really cool . i started playing again, the battle arena came out, and again it was awesome. then the tech tree was removed. I was mixed about this, but in the end i though it was for the better. recently the modules and new weapons came out. i though some of them were interesting, unique and generally really good. it had its downsides (e.g aeroflak 1 hit kill)  Now this....   The well done, fun, BALANCED, interesting game i knew was gone. now, robocraft is a low quality, pay-to-win cash cow. Im outraged. before i was playing with snipers and planes, hovers tanks and even the odd heli.it was great, balanced and fun. Now i join a game, with my plasma tank, and instantly die from a lock on missile, or an invisible teleporting ion cannon, or spiders, or photo seeker mini-bots. I lose instantly, and what does this mean? i get rusted crates, because i get rusted crates, i can't improve my bot, because i can't improve my bot , i can't do better, if i can't do better, i get Rusted crates and so on. the only way out is to pay a S*** load of money

I used to consider paying money, but now? i would never pay money to the money greedy Corporation freejam has become!I will now change my review to negative. Please Freejam, revert while you still can.( new edit:   the new update, battle for earth, has come out. the map looks cool, and thats about it, get ready to embrace the mech legged plasmas and missile heli-bots. I spent ages winning a game, i came first. and i got a gold crate. with 10 light chassis. and 10 slope chassis.GG Freejam)

- Dobzhd

reviewText:
Product received for free

Early Access Review

I've been a long time player of robocraft (like a year or two) it USED to be a great game. As with every ftp game theres a grinding element, but it was a rewarding one you'd grind for  days all while leveling u and unlocking new parts in your tier branch until finally you moved up a tier. Now you ether drop a bunch of money on crates or you grind for maybe a week to get the 1 part you want. Also you can sell almost your entire inventory and still not have enough robits to buy the one gun you want, only to have someone open a rust tier crate and get said gun. Does that sound like a rewarding grind system? No. I enjoy the new no tier aspect of the game but the recycle value of parts combined with the cost for new parts, or the very low chance of getting that part in a crate has broken the game.

For the new players that are wondering whether they should join, currently the game is a mess and the new loot system is the main problem. reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let me start off by saying this: the game isn't bad.

This game is certainly a lot of fun. If you're just searching for a game in which to screw around with friends, this is a game you won't regret giving a try. I personally have had some good times with this game, especially in a rather small amount of time.

However, if one is to don the identity of a critic, there's a lot of interesting points to bring up, both good and bad.

As if we're in a cheesy 1970's action movie, we'll start off with the bad, and then work our way to the good.

THE BAD:

1.
This game has some of the weirdest (and no, I don't mean wacky/enjoyable) physics I have had the ultimate displeasure to lay my precious eyes on. Seriously.
In the FIRST game I joined (with, admittedly, a precariously built little WALL-E that obviously couldn't tell which of its sides was which) , I found myself flipped in the first thirty seconds. Helplessly, I tried comming in the chat for one of the other new WALL-E clones to try and flip me over. Thankfully, they obliged to give it their all, which in the end meant nothing because robot collisions are barely even a thing in this game. You can ram into a tiny little 3-block retardcycle at full speed, attempting to move him a centimeter, and he won't budge at all. However, as he does not budge, you go flying at the speed of a middle-aged mother attempting to buy the next installment of mommy porn.
And of course, you flip over at the smaleST GODADCNM THIBGN FCKUK EVRFY ♥♥♥♥IN TMEIE I DRIVE ROTBOT IT FLIP VOER YWUFVU VDD WEFIDFH.

Second on the list of the bad:

Balance is nonexistent. If you disagree, I challenge you to go find a railgun-user who doesn't at least admit that the railgun is incredibly overpowered. Plasma cannons are pretty close after the railguns as well, completely outclassing SMGs in the first 4-5 tiers of the game, especially after a certain update that shall go unnamed until later on.
Recently, the developers have made efforts to change this incredible gap in the risk-reward/skill-payoff differences between the weapons. It still hasn't been enough, it seems. I've taken a pretty big break from the game now, and I don't expect to be picking it up much sooner if the balance in SMGS/Rails/Plasmas doesn't drastically, and I mean ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ DRASTICALLY change.

oh but afx ur just urmad cuz ur gt rekt (xd) by ppl whu r butter than uuu!!!11"

Un-equip the railguns/plasma cannons
date: give yourself the equivalent of a new player's robot
recommended:
and then survive more than 2 rails in a tier one game.

Third on the list:

Omfg. July 31st/August 1st

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I really loved this game once upon a time. It had everything I was looking for, freedom to build, pretty casual attitude, but competitive community, pretty even spread in weapon useability...but it seems like in recent updates, starting with megabots they just keep shooting themselves in the foot.
First was Megabots:
Megabots was a miserable addition. You build a giant tanky SMG bed and that's it. The plasma option has never been worth building because of the sheer lack of damage of the cannons and the armor of the top tier bots. All high level games became defend your megabot and hope to god they are semi-competent.

Next they decided to push toward moba... This was an interesting idea exccept that in the weeks I tried to play it after that update all matches were bombarded with one side or the other running into glitches that either made it impossible to finish the match or impossibly one sided on objective since you couldn't capture them. This persisted over the course of a couple months until I just stopped trying to play for a while.

Now they have...whatever they have now. Megabots are in the same spot with either smg or....smg because you still don't use plasma if you want to win. Matches are taking several minutes to queue as opposed to about 10seconds back in the earlier releases. FFA is what you'd expect, just a moshpit of gunfire. The maps still add little-no flavor to the game besides a few that were around since the start anyway.
I guess I can say the CPU load and how blocks unlock now is pretty nice for freedom to build, but that's pretty much the only thing I've seen that got better.

Just a minor grievance in addition, the automatic flipper is still crap.

Just get away from Robocraft, especially if you are thinking about whether to start playing this game or not. If you have fun getting disconnected from battles quite frequently (Suprise: if its league, you will lose your rank, even if the dc is rc's fault [which in most cases, it will be]), getting hit by invisible projectiles, desynced players shooting your butt or just the terrible matchmaking putting you into matches where the enemy will have end-game crafts while you just started playing the game, you will enjoy this game.
Have I mentioned the terrible matchmaking yet?

Good alternatives to Robocraft: From the Depths (Early alpha building game, lots less bugs than RC, really fun!) and Scrap Mechanic, a multiplayer building game (No fighting, I believe, havent played it).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

tl;dr In the latest update, the game changed its intuitive and fun play model to a random/gambling model that's unintuitive and not fun.

First off, I have to say that this used to be a good game. Before this latest update, you fight using pre-built robots to earn robopoints, use robopoints to buy parts needed to improve your robot's design. You repeat this process of building and fighting repeat until you've built a set of excellent robots. It was an excellent model that works and I loved it so much I've spent money supporting this game and have spent thousands of hours playing it.

This latest update changed it all. Instead of earning robopoints from fighting in matches, players now earn crates that reward random stuff when opened. And by random, I mean completely random. A crate may contain a single wheel or a single wing, which is completely useless as wheels and wings must be paired. I can no longer get the exact parts I need to complete my robot. Instead, I have to recycle parts I don't want for a heavily discounted price before I can craft" the parts I actually need. In order to build great bots
date: I now have to grind hundreds to possibly thousands of matches to gather all the parts that I need. This level of grinding is not fun for me and I has made me give up on this game.\n"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Good Ideas since before the Battle Arena Update
Painting... Maybe. it devalues cosmetic and makes artbots very pixel-focused in a voxel-avaliable game.
Electromania (Teir 10 Sheilds)
Megabots (When ~30% of games had them)
Curves and Aero Rods. The aesthetic is neat and some cool builds game out of them.
Overtiering Aversion (See Section 2)
New Maps such as Spitzer Dam
The Pit (See Section 2)Bad Ideas since before the Battle Arena Update
The Entirety of the battle arena update
Battle arena. Respawning. Commitment. Moba Structure. Slow Gameplay. Literally WWI Simulator.
Health Regen. What were they thinking?
Overtiering Aversion. For something so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ simple you think they could do it properly? Instead it just made people with immense amounds of RP kings as opposed to those with access to upper tiers. (I.E Gunbed Meta)
The Pit having a winner. ever.
Removal of the Seat system. The new damage model caters for the <2 hour players that Freejam statistics say apparently buy more GC. thanks, analytics.
Everything has gone toward catering for newbies. There are only so many steam users that give a damn about this kind of game, freejam!
Addition of Weapon and movement types... in a way that doesn't serve purpose to the meta. Sure, release mech legs and whatever the heck you want, but
You made bloody GLASS and HEADLAMPS cost GC? JESUS CHRIST.
PREMIUM ONLY PAINTS? THIS MAKES NO SENSE. THIS IS JUST BAIT, GC PAINTS? SURE.
Removal of the tech tree. There goes the motivation source for people climbing tiers
Removal of tiers. I guess somebody realised that <2 hour players don't like not having everything on a platter. Except Premium items, of course, which they apparently buy by the barrel and then ditch the game.
Lowering of skill ceiling and raising of pandering floor. Addition of weapons that aren't skillshot or aiming based.
The New UI. Reduced focus in the game from building, even though the skill floor for building still remians high for most types. Freejam is fighting a losing battle against it's own game. It baffles me why they didn't just make a new one.
Integrated A NEW GRINDING SYSTEM THAT COMPLETELY UNDERMINES THEIR PREVIOUS INTENTS, BUT THAT CAN BE SKIPPED WITH MONEY, HELLOOOOOO <2!
Killed megabots, see ya, Pro number 3!
Multiple weapons on one craft, Again, Taking away the emphasis on building. Mana system? Jesus christ. What happened to mastering your own creation? did they ever enjoy their own game?
I HAD ABILITIES ON MY OLD CRAFTS, YOU KNOW WHAT THEY WERE? EJECTOR SEATS,  A MEDIC FRIEND, ALIGNMENT RECTIFIER DODGING, FLIPPING OVER USING A HELITANK. WHAT HAPPENED TO THOSE ABILITIES, FREEJAM? YOU KILLED THEM WITH DUMBED DOWN MECHANIC CHANGES. I GUESS CLEVER DESIGN ISN'T AS EXCITING AS LOSING MANA. (/rant)
The killing of thrusters, in general, by the meta.I'm not even going to comment on epic loot, yeah? it's been done to death. anybody who liked robocraft for different reasons than me, sure, you can disagree with the whole post for all I care, but united we are at that awful system.
