reviewText:
Early Access Review

(Updated 2016/05/16)

If you are new to Robocraft, I do not recommend playing this game for several reasons, the most important of which is that I believe Robocraft is now leaning toward Pay To Win as a result of the recent so-called Epic Loot" game patch. Instead of trying to make a fun
recommended:
FreeJam is placing an emphasis on new player retention and money through psychological manipulation.

Random Rewards
With the introduction of Epic Loot
hoursPlayed: all in-game rewards given for playing have been converted to Crates. Opening a Crate will give you a random item reward
voteText: such as building blocks
helpfulPercent: a weapon
votesHelpful: a radar jammer
votesTotal: etc. A better score in the game will yield a higher level Crate. Higher level Crates have a slightly better chance of yielding higher level items. If you don't like the item you get
votesFunny: you can "Recycle" (sell) the item for in-game currency: "Robits."\n\nOn the surface this sounds fine. However
commentsCount: in my experience
column16: after playing hundreds of matches in the new system
column17: my in-game Robits balance has moved only very slightly. Why?\n\n* Rewards are random. I have yet to win a "Legendary" item
column18: the most valuable tier of items. I have won perhaps 2 or 3 "Epic" items
column19: and a handful of "Rares."\n\nThe thing is
column20: it feels like there is no correlation between my performance and my rewards. I have not noticed any trend in the better crates giving me better rewards. It feels wrong. It feels like punishment. I'm not getting rewarded for doing better. I'm getting random rewards like pulling the handle of a slot machine.\n\n* Recycle values are very low. The resale rates are effectively a small percentage of what they used to be. So
column21: even after selling everything I win
column22: I have very little in the way of Robits.\n\nPrior to the Epic Loot update
column23: players were able to earn in-game currency ("RoboPoints" or RP) by playing the game or by purchasing a separate game currency ("Galaxy Cash" or GC.) Players were rewarded with RP based roughly on their performance in game matches. The more expensive modules would take several days of playing
column24:
perhaps a few dozen matches. Progress was a little grindy but tolerable.

My progress after Epic Loot has ground to a halt. It was like hitting a brick wall.

Buy Crates!
The option
column25: of course
column26: is to buy crates for real life money. I understand developers need to make a living. However
column27: the crates you buy are STILL full of random junk. The rates for Legendary items even in the purchased crates are still under 5%
column28: which means you can spend US$25 and still not get a Legendary.\n\nEven if you sell all of the items you got out of crates with that $25
column29: it might not be enough to afford one Legendary item.\n\nIn contrast to this
column30: prior to the patch
column31:
you could purchase one of those Legendary items for $5 or less.

Deceit
My biggest problem with the update is that the currency names and scales were converted in an attempt to obfuscate how drastically the in-game currency earn rate was nerfed. The amount of Robits you earn from selling back items you don't want is much lower than the comparable earnings prior to the Epic Loot change. FreeJam is attempting to deceive and confuse players by changing the numbers on all of the items.

Weapon Balance
column32: Quality of Life
column33: Clans
column34: etc.\nThese things are important
column35: but they're not the most important thing. They don't speak to the integrity of FreeJam. As a developer myself
column36: I know balance is hard. I know development can be slow. I know social features are complex.\n\nBut if you try to pull the wool over my eyes and deceive me about what you're doing
column37: if you try to put me in a Skinner box to milk me for money unfairly
column38:
I'm done. You've revealed that all you care about is sales.

Summary
I have played Robocraft for years. I have been around through a lot of changes to the game. This recent change is a blatant money grab and shift towards Pay To Win. It is deceitful to the players. I would recommend staying away from Robocraft until this latest fiasco has settled down

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you've never played Robocraft before and are wanting to give it a try, don't. Those awesome robots shown in the images? You won't be making any of those. Once upon a time, not so long ago, you could. But it is not so now.

See, the game would reward you after every battle with a kind of in game currency based on your performance, allowing you to pick and choose parts to build robots with. This allowed for a great amount of creativity and encouraged you to get out there and cause mayhem, as it meant more money for the parts you wanted.

Now though, as of the most recent update, instead of cash, you are given a random assortment of bits and bobs to construct robots with, curbing the creative potential by an huge amount. These can be sold for money but even then you're not making anywhere near as much as you would with the old system. Add to that the grossly inflated prices for parts and any kind of meaningful progression is nearly impossible.

Don't waste your time with this game. If you're looking to get creative there must be a hundred games that give you the basic freedom to build what you want, as you want. Or just buy some lego.

Yep, the more you pay, the stronger you get, as you currently cannot gain anywhere near enough points from disassembling to afford anything beyond basic weapons, which have no effect against half the enemies you face now, while any damage you manage to do is now made pointless as the enemy will just hide behind a rock for five seconds behind his team, regenerate everything, and proceed to pop back out and one shot you with ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ homing missiles or something as rediculous. reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great concept, building new bots and taking them into battle is amazing - like lego with lasers and lock on missiles.
The developers at FreeJam, however, have made the game's balance and economy consitently worse with each update. The new Ion Distorter shotguns are insanely powerful, while the protoseeker has been nerfed to the ground. Nano's require huge amounts of energy to operate, making combat medic bots unviable. The economy has been shifted from a linear progression system to a flattened one, which is good in theory, but Freejam ♥♥♥♥ed it up.  All items in the game (blocks, guns, shields, etc) are now dropped from chests, which restricts building options and player creativity  - I've been waiting for modules to drop for days. One time I completely ran out of normal cubes, and had to grind singleplayer for enough cubes. You can recycle dropped items for currency, which is used to buy specific, individual parts, but the prices on these parts are so high that you're better off waiting for the small chance that the legndary weapon you need drops.
I'm not sure if they're trying to kill off all their old players to attract new players who never got to play this game at its peak.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is an amazing cross between Minecraft and World of Tanks. You build a vehicle, add weapons, and take it onto the martian landscape for battle! reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI've been playing Robocraft since July of 2014 shortly after it was released from beta, and I can honestly say that this game is one of the most fun games that I have ever played; I just keep coming back to it! The concept is simple: make a block out of armor cubes, stick it to a pilot seat, and slap some wheels and guns on it, too. Just like that, you have a working robot that you can use to drive around and fight other players and their robots. You start out small, but eventually you level-up further and further until you can make huge, complex crafts with shields, wings, hoverblades, triforced" armor... Tons! Each robot takes real-time damage during battle
date: which means that parts of your robot will fall off once enough damage is dealt to them; this adds a whole new dimension to combat and thought when building a robot.\n\nRecently
recommended: the game has gotten a lot of flak because of the implementation of the new MOBA gametype "Battle Mode
hoursPlayed: in which your team must fight the opposing team to capture and control 3 towers on the map to aid in destroying the enemy base. Older players grew accostumed to playing Classic Mode" (now called "Team Deathmatch") and complained about the new addition of Battle Mode
voteText: failing to realize that CLASSIC MODE (TEAM DEATHMATCH) STILL EXISTS. Whereas in Battle Mode
helpfulPercent: players respawn after being killed and focus on taking/retaining towers for their team

votesTotal: ~10v10 combat
votesFunny: no towers
commentsCount: and -- if you are in a high enough tier -- a MEGA bot on each team. Mega bots are HUGE robots that players can build eventually. So yes
column16: Robocraft has two awesome gametypes that you may choose to play at your whim with the high chance of additional gametypes being added in the future.\n\nOne of the biggest strengths of Robocraft is how responsive the development team is. It is worth noting that the game is still in its alpha stage

column19: Reddit

column24: for instance) but they have ALREADY ACKNOWLEDGED these issues and have promised to fix them. Though FreeJam can't fix every mistake immediately
column25: they are extremely aware of what the Robocraft playerbase feels is wrong. Some examples when FreeJam did RIGHT was: when the servers got clogged with an explosion of new players (last summer) they got more servers within a week
column26: they implemented an anticheating software program when hackers became an issue which significantly reduced the amount of cheaters in games

I think a current issue that some new players may face is the brief tutorial the game offers. I would recommend watching a youtube video to learn how to properly play/make a good robot/learn the controls in the garage bay.

Overall
column32: I think Robocraft is a spectacular game even in its alpha state with a lot of promise for the future. The developers actively listen to their playerbase's concerns and always deliver solutions to their problems. I could not recommend this game anymore to anyone!"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The crate update killed the game for me. I tried to like it, I really did, but progression for gathering materials for your robots has stalled. Every robot has a Shotgun, I'm sick of seeing Mech Legs, and the balance of fights is tilted.

Before the updates, I had fun fighting, and sometimes winning, with art bots shaped like X-Wings, AT-ATs, and DeLoreans. After the update I need to put as many snipers as I possibly can onto an armomred square block, or be vastly underpowered doing anything else. Don't even ask me to put wings on something other than a spider-sniper build.

The devs clearly don't listen to the vast outcries of the players, so now they have one less player to worry about.

I've uninstalled.

I'll be playing Factorio if you need me.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

-Disclaimer- This preview was written during Early Access. Robocraft is subject to change.-

Despite the disclaimer above, Robocraft is already a pretty well oiled machine. Most of the features are working quite efficiently and the core mechanics are in place. There are plenty of things to love about Robocraft straight from go. The basic gist is you build a bot/death machine and battle it out against other peoples creations. Where the beauty of the game lies is in its creativity, from a floating pirate ship to a MechWarrior style walker, you never know what you are going to end up fighting. Robocraft is a multi-faceted game that has many layers of complexity, so I will do my best to break it all down but I may forget to mention something.

The first time I loaded up Robocraft I was greeted with an anti-cheat 3rd party software. Not my favorite thing in the world but more than welcome for this type of game. Aim-bots have ruined other games and I appreciate the extra safeguard. That being said, the game does actually take quite a while to load up all of its assets. Also the game crashed right after the long load up. Not a great first impression. I credit this to Early Access hiccups and reloaded the game with little to no problems.

Upon second load up, I was brought into the heart of the game, The lobby. I watched as my pre-made bot gently floated in circles and I waited. Nothing happened. What was I waiting for you ask? A tutorial or anything for that matter. Nothing came. So I began randomly clicking around. I felt dizzy and lost with the amount of buttons, however this isn't my first rodeo and especially not my first battle arena style game.

After clicking around, my curiosity led me to the build mode. After a minor pop-up that explained a few buttons. I wouldn't call this a tutorial more a crash course but I digress. The builder is exceptional! It reminds me of Space Engineers where you build things in first person view and can quickly change the direction of parts with a roll of the mouse wheel. You are given some basic parts but most unlock through the games leveling system and huge branching parts tree.

The way things work is that you unlock parts the more you level. You level by playing in matches and destroying other vehicles. After leveling you unlock that part for purchase. You don't get that part for free, just the ability to buy it. There are some ways around this but we will get to that later. The builder is quite extensive needless to say and a quick Google search of peoples creations is somewhat awe inspiring and impressive. Sadly my skills and blocks were inferior and building my own machine was not necessarily the best idea, not yet at least. The only problem I found was that I was very limited for the most part at the beginning of the game. The basic starting vehicles and parts work but they don't really make you feel like a bad ♥♥♥ or all that cool. Especially as you will more then likely see other people using the same vehicle with slight variations. Things don't really become all that unique and interesting until much farther into the tech tree and amassing a fortune of in-game currency.

After this, I jumped into one of the pre-made vehicles and got into battle mode. I was not disappointed at all. There are several modes and they add different objectives and themes. You have team deathmatch, a conquest type mode, and boss battle, my personal favorite. In boss battle, you and many smaller craft face off against 4 much bigger and advanced craft. This requires a great deal of team work and coordination on both teams part otherwise you end up dead very quickly. The same can be said for conquest mode, which features capture nodes that must be protected/assaulted to attain victory. In all, my experience with the battle modes was fast, visceral, and fun. Usually whoever shoots first wins but sometimes I managed to win, even if I was left heavily wounded. The only problem I found with combat was queuing up, which could take anywhere from 1 to 4 minutes per match. Which given that some matches last about the same length, was a bit much for my taste.

Graphically, everything was very nice with Robocraft as well. While the focus isn't on the environments, the terrain had some nice detail and good level design, offering multiple options for different kind of play styles. The focus is for sure on the vehicles and this shows quite nicely. From the crackle of energy as your plasma cannons fire, to glowing energy panels. The only thing I felt needed a bit of work was the way you exploded which felt more like a firecracker going off than an actual explosion.

The soundtrack was there. but I found it forgettable for the most part. However, I did love the sound effects. Robocraft is one of those games where you want to load up your own tunes and go to work. The options menu was rather robust with a decent amount of graphical options and rebindable keys.

So let's talk about the elephant in the room, the microtransactions. Now Robocraft is not P2W or pay to win, but more like pay to skip. If you are a premium user everything is a bit easier as you earn more RP(in-game currency) and double the experience. Aside from all that, you can also purchase GC which is a premium currency that you can use to purchase most things from parts to premium status. Mind you, level still applies to this, if you aren't the right level, you can't use something ahead of everybody else in combat. Where the lynch pin lies is in the Robo shop, which allows players to purchase premade bots for real cash. This auto levels them to that particulars bots level and tier, essentially skipping the grind and getting into the good stuff.

While this is far from a P2W scheme, the problem I see is that this makes the free to play aspect kinda lame. Grinding and getting up to that point is going to take you months of work where as some dude with twenty bucks did it in five seconds. Your time isn't valued here, your wallet is more important. You may be vastly more experienced in the game but getting anything done is going to be a nightmare due to queues and the way the experience system works. You are given experience based off your contribution, meaning if you have a couple of bad matches, expect zero experience.  Now one could argue that this is fair. The developer has to make money some how and development isn't cheap, also the player should be rewarded for coughing up some dough. The problem is that the free to play experience isn't as exciting.

It's like going to the Zoo and seeing only the animals feet because you didn't pay. On the other side of the pay wall they have a freaking petting zoo, and you get to ride a Cheetah. Which is a damn shame because in Robocraft you probably can make an actual Cheetah, just expect to do it in weeks-months of grinding or drop a few bucks and get that shiny Cheetah right away. Everything just feels heavily stacked towards premium accounts. This shows in every aspect of the game.

If you take anything from this review remember this, Robocraft is a game that requires LARGE amounts of time investment or some cash to get to the really cool stuff. The game runs well and the combat is fun but long queues and long load ups can drag the overall experience down. You can take everything I say with a grain of salt though, because the game is free to play. You have nothing to lose but time. So feel free to check the game out and make up your own opinion. Robocraft is fun and worth it alone for the boss battles and seeing the huge bots. I haven't seen many games like Robocraft, especially ones that let you have this much freedom to make whatever you want.

Robocraft might sound awesome. And honestly, it was. Until Freejam made it pay2win. Basically, right now its not Robocraft, its Robocrap. So, if it doesn't change, Robocraft will die. One of the most awesome free2play games will die.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ask me for a review on this before Respawned and Overclocked update? (30/04/15) I would give this a positive review BUT AFTER Resspawned and Overclocked update....... That's a whole new side....

Here's why-

Before Respawned and Overclocked, this game inspired team work revolving heavy towards flanking, sticking as one big cluster of brute force because of the arena type mode. Once dead, you're gone. Once they introduced medics; it revolutionised the whole battle mechanic on whether a team would succeed or perish further reinforcing the team staying together. Moreover, when FJ released the team balance patch, the battles would last sooooo much longer and be even more adrenalin filled so you wouldn't be paired with 5 other rail walkers and be crushed by a whole team of smg tanks. As medic you would feel so valuable; one of my favourite memories...

Megabots arrive. Some of the player base decides this was a bad move (this was where the game started to get controversial) however, in my opinion, this was even better because now the T10's would stick by the Mega's siding them in one big turf war. Those were the good days of RC.

30th of April arrives. Respawned and Overclocked. The danger of dying now gone; stupid bots start appearing virtually killing the cleverly thought out designs using tri forcing ect. Team work is gone; no need to stick together. If you die, you can just respawn again. Don't even get me started on medics... Before Respawned and Overclocked, medics were the top priority on kill list. But now they're just replaced with respawn. Again, no fear of dying. Megabots are restricted to the old mode where hardly anyone played because of the shiny new Respawned and Overclocked. (The megabots were still fairly new yet all the work seemed to just be abandoned). Even though arena mode is still here, it feels as if it gets no love anymore.

Robocraft Unleashed touches down. The removals of tiers and tech trees are here. This resulted in a huge backlash from the community as many veterans felt that all their progress was for nothing as it took ages to grind up to each tier and save up for new parts to find that it's no longer the case. In addition, going up a tier made us feel amazing and satisfied giving us a sense of progression. I can see FJ wanted to enable full creativity as many wanted but it just won't work.

To some up-

Robocraft used to be one of my favourite games and WAS a fun and enjoyable game. Simple and easy to learn. However, as the updates passed, Robocraft got more and more complicated destroying the fun and simple factors or the arena game mode into a supposed 'moba' style game...

ps: if you read all of this; thanks for your time!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Excellent and unique game concept, ruined by RNG boxes and bad game design, in the name of money.
This game had potential, but unfortunately the developers elected to slow progression and rework rewards in an attempt to induce compulsory play (read: addiction), and force people to buy hundreds of RNG lottery boxes and a premium subscription... which, to my knowledge, has had the opposite effect.

Unfortunately, the changes didn't just affect the reward system, either - they added several huge, overpowered new weapons, many of which have auto aiming or aim-assist features that drastically reduce the required skill level to score well in matches, as legendary" items that might drop from the RNG boxes maybe 0.5% of the time
date: presumably in an effort to keep people hooked. One of the weapons - "AeroFlak" - also functions as a hard counter that renders one of the most interesting types of robot to build and play - aeroplanes
recommended:
such as interceptors and bombers - largely useless.

They have also publicly stated that they effectively refuse to address either of these problems in any meaningful way.

Even though the community had warned them about it for weeks (ever since the announcements for the changes) through every possible channel.

And even though the community has been suggesting hundreds of viable solutions to the issues created by the new system.

Just look at the recent State of the Game post

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game used to be amazing! I stopped playing for a few months. Then I came back to find pretty much everything that made the game work so well, replaced with a terrible new broken system.

The bot tier system that worked so well is replaced with this horrible bot ranking thing that pits you against pretty much random levels of bots. Half the time I was going in with my old T6 tank I was getting pitted against bots with almost max everything... How the heck is that better than the bot tier system that was very transparent and easy to work with for the players.

Then there is almost no feeling of progression anymore because they did away with the tech tree! I mean WHAT!? How dumb do you have to be as a game developer to pull something like that. PLAYERS LIKE PROGRESSION and it was working fine. Now you just get everything unlocked.. woop-de-do that was so rewarding... NOT

To top it all off every time I went to join a game it would say average wait time ~30 seconds. Yet it took me on average 4-6 minutes to join a match that maybe lasted 3 if you dont die right away.

This used to be a wonderful game. I loved it and put money into it. Now the developers have run it into the ground. It is very sad because I was super excited to play me some good ol robocraft again and spend some more $$ on it to catch up since I left it for a few months.

R.I.P. Robocraft, Your developers ruined you...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL;DR
This game was great but it turned into a pay-to-win and most players become selfish because of the new updates.You needed some skills to build bots before but you can build complete nonsense now. The removal of tiers system is just bad.
This game used to be fun when you actually needed to specialise in one class and cooperate with the whole team in order to win. You could earn money no matter what, then you could buy whatever you want for your bots and upgrade them.

However, with the recent updates (the implementation of crates system and the ability to put mutiple classes of weapons onto one bot), people can just spam craps onto one bot and rush to the top of the scoreboard in order to get some slightly better ♥♥♥♥. Most players become selfish and only focus on scores because only the top player on the scoreboard can get the protonium crate (better ♥♥♥♥). Also, you can't earn anything except crates and XP from battles (AKA no money and crate is basically everyting).

The worst part is that even if you can get the protonium crate, you can still get cheap ♥♥♥♥, because the items in it are distributed randomly and not performance-based. Normal players seldom get what they want from crates. You can still buy stuff, but they changed the in-game cash to robit which can only be obtained by destroying other stuff you own and it only gives very little amount of it, you can only get back 10-25% of what the original value is (you could get back 50% of the original value in the old system). Players can buy crates that cost real money and try to get what they want (even if they can't get what they want they can still destroy those buttloads of stuff from those buttloads of crates and buy whatever they want). This makes it really hard for new players who don't want to spend real money to upgrade their bots to higher level. And old players (me) usually bought everything they need from the good ol' days and good ol' system, which is extremely unfair to new players.

The removal of pilot seat is also a really big mistake. The pilot seat allowed players to make something creative but reasonable because you needed to build something that could protect the pilot seat (basically you needed skills to build something). Now you can just build something completely ridiculous since there isn't a pilot seat anymore.

I don't want to make this review too long so I will just say the removal of tiers system is just a really really poor decision.

Early Access Review

Don't be fooled by its lego appearance and dull looking terrain, the battles are very fun (especially boss battles) and building your bot is fantastic, a little slow at first but picks up greatly in the mid tiers

All the different combinations you can make with the free form building makes all tiers much more interesting than other games like 'World of Tanks' or 'War Thunder' where you're so limited that it can get dull trying to work your way up.

Aside from a few server issues on special event days, I have yet to experience many problems with server stability and the requirements to play it properly are extremely low.

I'd recommend that everyone at least give it a shot, I wouldn't have if someone hadn't told me.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After playing this game for over 30 hours and progressing through 4 (almost 5) tiers, I think I'm qualified to write a good, informed review. The concept of this game is to build a functioning robot (it isn't really a robot due to the fact that you have a pilot seat, but that's beside the point) out of the parts they give you, then take this robot into battles. The more you fight with your robot, the more currency you earn (represented by RP) along with Tech Points, which are used to unlock new parts, which are then bought with RP. You must also use RP to repair your bot if it is damaged in battle, and the repair costs varry depending on just how damaged your bot was. Currently, there is only one gamemode in which you must capture the opponent's base before they capture yours. So, if you're a fan of varrying gamemodes I can't really recommend this to you...yet.

One major thing that I feel like I should address is that this game does include microtransactions. BUT, before you hear that word and automatically deny the existance of the game, the game is not pay to win in the way that you would be able to notice it while playing a match, and arguably not pay to win at all. The reason for this is that the game works by matching up your bot with other bots which fit in your tier (I saw one of the reviews not recommending the game complaining that they are constantly matched with players in tiers higher then themselves, but I have never had that experience in over 30 hours of gameplay). Due to this system, someone who buys the best parts in the game is going to be automatically moved into the highest tier in the game, where they will still not gain an advantage over other players. If anything, those who pay for parts would have a disadvantage due to the fact that they are not as experienced in building their robots or fighting with them. Building off of my last sentence, the way you build your robot is very important. Someone with the lowest avaliable items in a tier with a well designed bot could still defeat someone with the highest weapons in the tier with a badly-designed bot.

Another major aspect of this game is progression through levels. The only time this game gives me the feeling of grinding is after I've maxed out my robot for the tier I'm in but I don't quite want to step up to the next tier yet, which is really only a limit I put on myself. There is rarely a time (in the first 4 tiers anyway, I haven't progressed to the tiers above so I can't speak for those yet) when you get back from a battle and can't afford to upgrade your robot in a at least a minor way, such as upgrading a few sheets of armor. Due to this constant ability to upgrade at least something, I never really feel like I'm grinding away at the next level, but rather slowly progressing through the level towards the next one, something I really enjoy.

All in all, Robocraft is a game with a great premise, currently limited gameplay elements (in terms of gamemodes) and a few glitches, but those are to be expected in early access games. I would recommend it to anyone who has ever wanted to be able to build and use the vehicle you take into battle and don't mind the fact that there is curently only one gamemode. To those who are turned away by that fact, there are still 3 maps which provide areas for using different strategies with different robots, adding some sort of variety into the gamemodes. Even if that still doesn't seem like enough of a redeeming factor, just try it anyway, as the worst that can happen if you end up absolutely hating it is that it took up some space on your computer and some of your time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Despite the recent updates and many complaints about them, I find this game to still be quite fun. Some of the major complaints are regarding the recent additions of CPU limits and armor tier locks, as well as the removal of all overtiering. While it affects the game, sure, it is not 'game-breaking' in the sense that we cannot play the game.

The main piece of advice I would give to new players is to not rush tiers. The new update was poorly thought through and hence a new player can rush from tier 1 to tier 10 in a matter of hours whereas for me it took almost 200 (I launched the application directly for probably half my playtime instead of through Steam). The advantage of taking your time in each tier is that you become a better player and have a much higher player level by the time you reach tier 10. If you tier-rush, you will likely arrive at tier 10 with a player level of 5 or 6, not nearly enough to be at all competitive in T10.

The game is still very fun, despite the changes, and I think the new meta has revived a dying game, which many of my friends quit because it was getting boring. I strongly strongly recommend this game as long as you avoid tier-rushing :)

This is my first review on any of the countless games i have on steam, yet it is a review that saddens me.

Betrayed and let down are the feelings that come to mind.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Finally I will review this game.  I really couldn't be bothered.  This game is so mediocre that it is hard to describe.  I will point out a few things I liked and how they changed.

Liked:  The tech point system.  It directly rewarded you on how you played.  Play good.  Get stuff.  Play bad.  Get stuff much slower.

Liked:  The toned-down approach to pay to win.  It was there, sure.  But it wasn't in your face.

Liked:  Gameplay.  It was fun.  Simple.  Incredibly so.

Disliked:  The lag.  The spikes.  The network issues.  That the game automatically punished you for (disco bugs that enforced a wait period to play again.  What?  Am I at work?  Uninstall.)

Disliked:  Once you felt like you were getting ahead changes were made.  Big changes.  Got that awesome railgun that you been playing all week to afford?  Boom!  Nerfed on accuracy, reload and speed of bolt.  How about those 14 or so laser blasters you installed after fighting like a dog for a week to earn?  Boom!  Nerfed!  Accuracy out the window after three shots and ranged reduced by a third.  This basically goes for all weapons and mods in general.

Disliked:  The feeling of never getting to breathe because of all the sudden changes that were so sweeping and so often in implementation.  The game has probably been reworked in either level system, weapons changes, physics, research model, grind model or gameplay as to make it almost feeling like being at work.

Disliked:  The latest patch.  It has gone fully out the window.  All the effort since 2014 (on and off from frustration) just gone out the window.  All my grinded parts gone.  Just gone.  Revamped.  Now they have a random loot reward system at the end of every match.  Before you would fight well and get paid well.  Now you fight well or bad and an RNG roll decides what you get.  YAY!  I just rolled 20 common cubes!  Nice!  Because I needed 3020 of them!  All those uncommon and hard to get toys you worked for you have to work to get all over again.  And guess what!  They are insidiously expensive now.  But oh!  Wait!  You can make a roll and get them by chance if you play!  Play more and get more chances.  Great!  I should also mention that you get double the loot if you have premium.  Yes!  Pay us and you get double the chances to get what you want (you already had it and they patched it away from you but none of that talk!) and all will be well.  I should note that the vast majority of rolls I did make did have all the rares and legendary items up in the premium roll area.  For me down here it was 20 cubes and lvl 1 wheels.

Uninstalled.  Forgotten.  Not recommended.

P.S.  Take note I do not write reviews often.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nWith the release of the Epic Loot update, I have come to the conclusion that this game is no longer worth playing. But now, it's just another crate simulator, grind and grind to get one single item, then scrap it and grind some more. That's not what this game was about a long time ago, but that's what it has devolved to. Goodbye Freejam, I won't be using your products again anytime soon. You ruined something promising.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The loot crate update killed this game.

Prior to the last major update, I would've strongly recommended this game. Its core gameplay is unique and it's a ton of fun to bring vehicles you build yourself. But changing the progression from a quick, quality-driven system to a total RNG nightmare makes the quality of the building and gameplay meaningless. Thanks to harsh RNG gating off players' abilities to build vehicles, which is the core of this game, and players no longer being able to just buy parts with currency earned from gameplay performance, there isn't any reason to get into the game in its current state.

Let's start this off by saying I really...REALLY want to rate this game thumbs-up, but seeing the changes implemented since early 2015, I simply can't.

When I first started playing Robocraft (Late 2014) it was an amazing game. They had a tech tree system to level up your equipment, you were able to purchase gear from a shop, by winning games you got currency, etc. But ever since the removal of the tech tree, this game has just been on a trip of steady decline.

In recent updates, they have removed the ability to freely build your vehicle. The only way I have found to get new parts and accessories is by opening Crates" to get "loot." You can then keep the loot
date: or recycle it to buy other items. I feel that this puts the whole "Construct your own robot" idea in the trash. I mean
recommended: this completely decimates the whole point of the game: being creative and constructing your own vehicle. It makes it so that you can only get 1 part at a time from each box (2 if you pay $$ for premium).\n\nThey also removed the vehicle tier system. The whole system of tiers and and the tech tree was perfectly fine

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After 'the epic loot' it became certain, that Robocraft devs tried hard to monetarize each aspect of the game. Instead of progressing toward a richer building/crafting/fighting experience, they removed the faculties I liked the most (those capable of introducing teamplay for instance, or those that made victory dependant on skill). Each and every update they uttered some fluffy bla on how they are going to listen to their community next time.. then iterated on how 'their vision' of the game is grand and nice and still moved at least three steps backwards, for each step forward. I played this game alot, until their 'vision' became a toxic influence of ♥♥♥♥ing over established metagame with every update. They might not wanted to be destructive, but they are. What they never get is, that they were fixing problems they introduced themselves, Now with half of the old community already gone, they feel free to squeeze the last juice out of this once good game.  Who likes to open crates with random junk, when he could have the desired item bought directly. Nobody. But I dont want to create the idea, that the only abominable thing Freejam did, was the 'epic bull' update. No..no.. They had repeatedly the audacity to null my ingame cash balance with their updates,  - or similar.
It first happened when tiers were removed: the week before I purchased tier 11 blocks for several billions, only to have them removed without refunds , with an 'upgrade' to their vision. Then they removed the Megabots, the one and only goal for a lvl 100 player. This meant removing several multi billion credit items, many players bought with ingame cash/ premium cash. Without a real refund. (well you got a stupid energy carger module, for each megabot)
Well after all this Ripoff and Abuse, I stopped playing for a while, because of my old gamer buds, nobody cared about this game anymore. But with the 'loadout' upgrade I convinced some of this group to rejoin the game and play with me. That happened for a glorious week or two, until they decided to implement their ♥♥♥♥ing skinnerbox ripoff abuse lootgame. While they were trying to hijack my endorphin-receptors with their 'casinovision' of theirs, they silently removed 9000 units of premium cash and offered no refund except a protonium crate with 20 blocks.

So now I stopped wasting my time/money on greedy idiots with a vision.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Me (At Launch): I like this game! It's a unique vehicular-based shooter where teamwork and communication are the keys to success! Sadly, this game is filled with 10 year olds, but even without communication its a cool time killer. You get to design your vehicle fairly easy, and its pretty cool that everyone has a different machine, adding a large amount of diversity to the game. To get cubes to build your vehicle, you earn a currency during matches that you can buy cubes with and you unlock more cube with a different currency. There is another currency that costs real money, but it buys the same thing as the F2P currency and a couple cosmetics but that's it. A very fun game.

Me (Later): Ok they changed the game a little bit, in ways i don't really like, but it is still an ok game. You still have the F2P currency and the P2P currency but now you don't need to unlock the cubes. It makes it so someone can take a Super-OP gun and put it on their tiny vehicle and it gets grouped up with the weak-vehicles with 20 very-weak guns. It doesn't matter how small the OP vehicle is because it kills anything that it sees instantly. There is also now a community" market

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I used to play this game every day.  I reached level 100 when there were still block tiers, which actually doesn't seem that long ago. A year ago, I would've, and did, recommend this game to several people. Now, I can't. The balance at every level is ♥♥♥♥, At high level, it's gridlocky spam garbage. I can't even play low level deathmatch because my rank is incorporated into matchmaking, so even if I make a bot that's four blocks long with the worst wheels and a single cheap gun, I could be matched up against ridiculously well built bots that were made by lower level players.

I used to try new builds pretty much daily, but innovation isn't rewarded now. I used to fly, but there are now three highly effective AA platforms. Long ago, air was superior, then it was terrible, then briefly great again, now it's worthless. I hope you like to make multiblade copters or tanks because that's all there is at the highest level.

There used to be a sense of progression and a whole new set of things to try and get, but now everything is tierless and your robot is judged on its size. And man, the RNG loot crates sure are wonderful. Instead of getting a currency reward that I can use in the shop to purchase parts I want, I get random trash from a pool of parts and get to throw unwanted parts into a blender and get worthless scrap 'robits'.

I miss what this game was and could've been. Freejam has been so focused on crafting a garbage, balanced"
date: build-your-hero MOBA that they lost the fun
recommended: casual team-based vehicle battle game that this used to be."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Robocraft is a game about building your own robot from a huge numbers of part and battle against other robots in a third person style shooter.

As you can see, I spent a long time with the game and really, really liked it. Unfortunately, the direction the developer decided to take isn't mine. In the past, you had a performance based reward system that made it easy to get the parts you need to build a robot.

Now, the reward system is largely based on luck and randomness. Good luck getting all the parts you need to build the robot you want in a timely manner. It's not possible anymore.

In the past, you could spend money to get part that you want. Currently, you can spend money on a lottery-like system (buying crates with random items). This system is proven to work for games like Hearthstone, but in a building game, where you need a certain amount of wheels, tracks or guns, to build the robot you like, this just isn't fair for the player.
voteText: 14 of 14 people (100%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has a brilliant premise, and given me a few hundred hours of enjoyment.  You build fighting robots out of armor cubes and stick functional movement and weapon components onto them.  Then you pilot them in a team vs. team environment.  The game plays quite smoothly, and the dynamic damage system lets you tear bots apart piecemeal, adding a level of precision to the combat that sets it above most vehicle shooter games.

Unfortunately, the developers lack any foresight when it comes to balancing, and it's gotten steadily worse with each update.  For example, they've added several highly specialized weapons that excel in certain situations but are highly limited in others.  This would be great if not for a relatively recent decision to allow you to place multiple weapon types on a bot.  The result was that bot diversity immediately plummeted, as everyone can now build bots that have no weaknesses or limitations.

Imagine what Team Fortress 2 would be if the sniper was also issued a rocket launcher and flamethrower, and that's the current state of Robocraft.  Sadly, the developers seem perpetually oblivious to the harm they're doing to their game, and every update over the past year has taken it from a brilliant class-based team shooter with an extra addition of clever robot engineering, and turned it into a unique but mediocre shooter with robots that are functionally indistinguishable.

I'll definitely be paying attention to it's continued development, in the hope that the developers significantly change tack.  Robocraft not only has the potential, but has flat out demonstrated, that it can be one of the best games I've played, but in its current state I wouldn't recommend it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

An update (800+hours of actual game play) and you should know I was really excited.
Epic loot update = disgusting. Premium rediculously increased and lowered in value. Rather than giving us new content they changed the numbers of damage/mass/armour values and called this an update.

+ Since the spectrum update, they did make league mode optional and thank you FJ for this.

The new 'epic loot' update, has killed a lot of the creativity. You spend 700 pflops (out of 1700 for your bot) and those guns do nearly nothing. The new meta is shotguns and rails (snipers). If you like this class then this game is for you.

The new loot drop system is uninteresting and leaves a void (for me) of the refreshing newness of prior robocraft days where you could move fast and shoot fast. The controls feel clunky, and there was no warning about the change of mass for their updates.

The part that is most disappointing is how much this game micromanages it's player base. Touted as a creation based system, every change is aimed at nerfing new builds that people come up with (or at least it feels that way), yet some of the most problematic abuses (tessaracts) that clearly violate the games physics (seriously corner cubes barely touch each other) are left in the game.

The loot drop system would bother me as a new player simply because i have to wait for items to appear. Got an epic item? Hope you are leveled enough to use it.

We were told there was going to be an epic update" and many of us were seriously excited for this. What they didn't tell you is that the real "epicness" of this update was that they were playing with numbers and calling it an update. No new game mode
date: no new maps.\n\nFinal notes on the loot system.  I have to say this being a game for young gamers

Well, now they are on damage control and posting fake apologies, but its a bit too little and a bit too late. Dont apologize, fix this game and revert far far back to when it was once a good game. You can make jets, hovercrafts, drones"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

REVIEW UPDATED, SEE BOTTOM

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I used to love this game, I really did. It was my favorite for a long time. Now I am forced to stop playing because the developers are flushing it down a toilet, and I'm not a piece of sh*t so I refuse to follow it on it's downward spiral to the cesspools. If they have some convoluted plan that saves their a$$es in the end, then I may pick it up again and change my review.

I've logged 350 hours in this game and now I think it's time for a review.

No amount of half-arsed compensation can make up for the loss of the Mega.
Sure, we can sell back all our mega-guns, but what the funk are we going to buy with all that cash? It's not like I can go and use it to build a Mega. Speaking of mega-guns, their presence is entirely useless now that we can't have enough CPU to use them.

They say the Megas were too big for the maps? I never had an issue ever. If you're going to own a large vehicle, you better be skilled enough to drive it.

And what's up with this new Fusion core? Another useless pile of scrap. Now that Mega bots are gone, we don't even need to worry about power consumption. And with the extreme CPU cost it has, there's no worry of having enough guns to eat all your power.

One possible reason the Mega bots were removed is because whiny children were complaining due to the fact that they DON'T have a mega. It's a case of the Have-Nots attacking the Do-Haves. Also, the Store page's video is now a complete lie of false advertisement due to the removal of the Mega.

The angry few are louder than the happy masses.




To the Devs: Please stop smoking crack on the job. It's impairing your judgement and causing you to make horrible decisions.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

GoodBuilding is like Minecraft for vehicles
Playing is hilarious. Parts get shot off and it realistically changes the vehicle’s handling. I’ve been left with nothing but one walker leg and used it to claw my way onto the enemy base and win for my team.
Not pay to win. Real money only unlocks things faster, it doesn’t give any battle advantage
Lots of freedom to mix and match parts to optimize vehicles' handling, speed, damage, and durability in auto-match team games
Movement: hovercraft, wings, wheels, treads, floating blocks, grippy walker legs, helicopter, skids, thrusters
Weapons: sniper, artillery, machine gun, energy ram, healing beam (also damages enemies)
Defense: armor cubes, various plates that absorb some damage without being damaged
Specials: radar, radar jammer, radar sharing, rods & beams, headlights
Your designs really matter. There are tricks- like you can build with voids and layers to protect the core by routing damage on longer paths
Lots of players. Half the fun is seeing what other people build
Good feeling of progression as you make money and invest it in your library of parts. Tiers went away, but I don’t mind.
Very active devs who listen to the players and update the game every couple weeks
Giant megabots. It’s so much fun to be a massive death dealer who shreds all the smaller bots. I’ve also taken a tiny healer with energy rams in so close to a megabot that its giant guns couldn’t focus on me. I burned several off before I guessed where the pilot seat was and tunneled in with the rams to kill it. When that huge thing shattered around me, leaving my tiny tiny bot victorious, it became the best of hundreds of great memories of the game.BadGenerally the anti-cheat works, but sometimes a hack gets through for a few days before a patch fixes it
There are glitches and bugs, but they’re minor
Some adolescent negativity and other nonsense in chat
The big one: updates renovate or erase big elements and people complain. In my view the devs take 5 steps forward for every 1 back, and the downvoters are just focussing on the 1. Look how all the negative reviews are from people with hundreds of hours in Robocraft. The truth is they love the game so much that relatively small problems upset them.
Because you battle with your own design, embodying your ideas about what’s effective and displaying your style- the battles feel personal. It’s not a fake experience like so many other games where they give you carefully controlled challenges made to be beat. It’s raw and real and chaotic. That’s what I love about it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have played tons of games on robocraft.  I have played this game since it was awarded indie game of the year, and might I say props to you for accomplishing that. That said, there are a few things that need to be taken into account:

Balance:
The game is EXTREMELY unbalanced, the auto lock on missiles are very hard to dodge and are expensive(more on this later) and now the timer has been dropped from taking 2.5 seconds to lock on, to 2 seconds. Not only is this devastating but the main weapons of the game: plasma cannons, and plasma lasers have taken some nerfs. Lasers have reduced fire rate and plasma cannons increase power consumption. This creates a huge divide from the premium users that paid money to get the missiles easily and the basic players who can only afford one laser of a high tier.

End game rewards (and money issues in general):
I consider myself to not be at the end game, but close to it. My weapons have gotten quite expensive as of late. To list off a few:
Top laser disintegrator: 959,549
Plasma devastator: 1,107,169
Disc Shield: 10,876,430
Blink Module: 10,507,740
Aeroflak Cannon: 11,071,688
Lock-on Missile Launcher: 10,149,047Now, this list wouldn’t be too bad, if the payoff was about 60,000~, 80,000~ with premium users in the game. Now, understandably it is frustrating that the most I can get in a game is 110,000~ with a first win of the day bonus and premium users. So, all in all you are required to play approximately 126.86~ games to acquire 1 lock-on missile launcher, let me emphasis this ONE LOCK-ON MISSILE LAUNCHER, and in order to be any use to your team, you’re going to want to pack at least 2 of them, making the amount of games you need to play skyrocket to 252~. This is unbelievable and give NO incentive whatsoever to grind out the game for the RP.
I can hear it now, how can I play this game if it takes so long to get something. Easy enough, you just have to pay real life money to obtain all of these weapons, problem solved. For translation it costs you 2,300GC for 1 missile launcher, that would approximate putting $2.50(and a little more to get 50 more GC) and to get two of them you need $5.00 for it. Doesn’t seem like a lot, but this is a “FREE TO PLAY GAME” Why then would you make the game free and then choose to make the game SUCH A HUGE GRIND that you cannot even begin to reach end game content without going past a pay wall or dedicating hours upon hours to a game.
Additional premium content:
On a side note, I have noticed that glass now costs GC to purchase, no RP method. The three principles upon which this game is built upon is “build, drive, fight” can you drive? Yes. Can you fight? Yes, now building on the other hand. Building has been limited in the terms of glass. Glass used to be a fun cool block that you can use in your vehicle to have, which is now gone, banished behind pay wall.
Things they did well at:
Fun and amazing gameplay
Large variety of game modes to choose from
Roboshop to help you get a ship if you suck at creativity
Have more than 3 bays for free
Testing area
Gaining RP for testing your ship against bots (although it is minuscule)I will update my review as major parts of the game are tweaked, but at the moment if given the chance to rate the game at its current state, I would give it a 4/10. This game is below average, it can perform meh compared to most free-to-play Minecraft cube copy games. However, the game still needs LARGE improvements before it can be considered a game to play.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So I've been noticing the increasing number of negative reviews for this game and the decreasing quality of the positive reviews, so I thought I would say something:

Many people are upset that many features of the game have changed, i.e. the leveling system and the locking of certain gamemodes to lower levels that were previously open. I do agree with some of these arguements...

HOWEVER.

This game is still absolutely fantastic. To those complaining about the gamemodes being locked to lower levels: The Team Deathmatch gamemode, in which you have only one life, will only help the lower levels learn more strategies than in Battle Arena, where you have endless lives and can just rush headfirst into battle, rather than sticking together and positioning yourselves according to your weaponry and armor. I also like the leveling system a lot more, because it is not nearly as tedious as the previous method of having to go through each unlockable with barely enough Tech Points and then realizing that you need to go back and get tech points from a previous tier, meaning that you would need to downgrade your bots. People argue that the old leveling system was harder and thus more fun, but it wasn't harder. It was tedious. There is a difference.

To sum it up: At least try this game. I think it is brilliant. If you don't like it, then that's okay, because it's free. Just delete it.

And to everyone that I can guaruntee will be ♥♥♥♥♥ing about me only liking the new leveling system because I'm a low level noob:    ♥♥♥♥ off. I'm level 74.

EDIT: So... the most recent update obliterated the main arguments of most complainers: the gamemodes are no longer locked! And they added a customization system, improved the crf, and simplified building stuff.

HOORAY!!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A fun idea, but executed in the most uninspired way possible. At first glance it looks like it could have all sorts of possibilities for crazy vehicles and constructions, but due to the very limited number of origional parts, all vehicles are basically a bunch of cubes with guns stuck on them and some wheels or jets. There are many parts you can buy, but they are all just the same parts made slightly better. The list of parts is, currently, as follows: structural blocks, (including square and angled bits,) wheels, jets, hover jets, flotation blocks, wings, armour plates, and three types of guns; basic slowish shot, lobbed shot, slow long range shot. Most of these parts, namely everything but the blocks, wheels and basic gun, is locked when you start, so to actually build anything besides a box with wheels and a bunch of guns tacked onto it you will have to either pay hard cash for them or put in many hours of play.
On top of all that, the only workable design for a vehicle seems to be your command seat surrounded by as much mass as you can pile around it, and as many guns as you can fit on the top and sides, because there is no strategy to the game other than drive toward the enemy and hope you can shoot more than he can.

To conclude this rambling, I would not reccomend this game in the least. If you think the developers may actually get around to making this game less of an uninspired blob of sadly unexplored concepts, by all means keep an eye on this game, but for now don't waste your time. Or your money.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Eat.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Please note that I am currently unable to play the game due to a crash at startup upon viewing a crate that I recievecd during a battle. I am not the only one experiencing this issue, and as far as I can tell, reports go back as far as two to three weeks ago with no answer from the developers or staff in any thread other than Don't bump threads". The official respons I got from a support ticket is recreated below:

"Hi
date:
Thanks for contacting Freejam Support!

This is an issue we are aware of and one we are currently working to fix as soon as possible.You should make sure to check the patch notes of our next update as information on bug fixes will be displayed there.

Thank you for your continued support and patience and we apologize for any inconvenience this issue may have caused.

Thanks again
recommended:
DanSupportJammer"

Below is my review of the game at this point. I have tried to remain as un-biased as possible with respect to the crash problem I mentioned earlier.

-------------------------------

Robocraft used to be a game about building robots and fighting to the death. It used to emphasize builder skill and fighting tactics like recognizing the weak points on your opponents robot.

Used to.

The game now heavily focus on a MOBA style game mode without minions where teams of 8-12 players capture towers across the map. Each tower captured increases their weapons effectiveness against capturing other towers and damaging the opposing team's main reactor. If your team captures all three towers
hoursPlayed: the enemy's shield around their reactor goes down. If your shield goes down
voteText: you can no longer heal when in close proximity of the reactor
helpfulPercent: and must instead avoid enemy fire to heal automatically.\n\nI built a quick robot that can capture a tower solo in the mid to late game in 5 seconds
votesHelpful: and I can easily solo the enemy's reactor if their shild is down in the late game in under 30 seconds. If you are on a team that knows how to capture towers quickly then the game will be over quickly
votesTotal: you will get a decent reward
votesFunny: and you can continue grinding. If however your team doesn't know what they're doing
commentsCount: frequently splits up
column16: and suicides into huge balls of enemies while the other team knows how to quickly captures towers
column17: your life will be miserable. You will get only up to the third lowest quality crate if you are top on the losing team.\n\nThere are other game modes
column18: currently a team-death-match and free for all
column19: but rewards for players in this game mode are so small that it really isn't worth it unless you already have most of the functional parts.\n\nNotice that I said "if you already have the parts". You are not rewarded with currency in this game unlike most other online games. Instead
column20: at the end of a match
column21: you are rewarded with a crate containing one or more random items ranging from armor and cosmetics to weapons and functional parts. The better you do
column22: the better the parts you will recieve (supposedly). Players who pay for the premium boost get twice as many items
column23: but do not have a higher chance at getting **better** items as far as I can tell. Items can be broken down into "Robits" that can then be used to craft parts that the player wants.\n\nUnfortunately
column24: this move has massively inflated the currency used by players. Under the old system
column25: sell-back value was exactly half that of the cost to purchase a part
column26: and players were rewarded with currency directly. Under the new system
column27: almost all parts are recycled into a measly 1/10 that of the price to buy a part
column28: effectively increasing the time required to grind out the robits needed to purchase the parts you want by at least 10 times (this ignores the fact that you **may** get the parts you want in a random crate drop
column29: but in my experience
column30: the system likes to give you 10-50 cubes instead which decompose into one robit each)\n\nSupposedly
column31: this has been improved a lot over the past week
column32: however as I mentioned before
column33: I am unable to verify as I cannot play the game currently due to crashes.\n\nThis game is littered with technical problems. Players getting under the map
column34: weapons that sometimes fire and sometimes don't
column35: special modules sometimes crashing the game for players
column36: graphical glitches
column37: and horrible de-sync errors which cause everyone to stop moving to your perspective. In this de-sync'd state you can still damage the enemy a little
column38: but as far as the game is concerned you have disgraced your team and quit
column39: thus you get no reward and are even punished for "leaving" early if you were playing the moba game mode
column40: which is very frustrating. Tech support swears that this is due to a misconfigured MTU setting on your router
column41: but numerous players can testify otherwise.\n\nFurthermore
column42: the developers seem to have no sense of direction. Sweeping change after sweeping change
column43: they keep steamrolling on ahead implementing new features
column44: weapons
column46: and completely changing many critical core mechanics
column47: forcing the players to adapt rapidly. This game uses the "alpha" and "early access" moniker as a massive crutch to hide behind the litany of issues and bugs the developers leave in their wake. The community technical support forum is a ghost town
column48: players reporting critical issues have their threads relocated there to never be responded to by any developer or staff member. This is sad really.\n\nOverall
column49: I would not recommend the game in its current state. Too much has changed
column50: and it feels like FreeJam are only listening to new players while shoving their fingers in their ears and ignoring the rest of the community.\n\nSadly
column51: this remindes me of a game I used to play: Battlefield Heroes by Dice / EA. Shortly before the open beta started
column52: the developers completely re-worked the way rewards worked
column53: massivly inflating the currency so that any player who wanted to progress at anything better than a sloth's pace was forced to spend money. The community split in two
column54: and many players never returned. I hope this game does not face a similar fate..."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Don't be stupid.. Look at the good reviews and their play time. I gaurantee not a one is over 100 hours or even close to it most are 40hours or less. So don't be fooled by fake reviews that developers make and sit in the game for a day or a few hours then use to boost recent reviews.
Or people like I said haven't played long enough to give a fair review. You can tell they are usually 1 liners.
Everything shown in the video above is no longer. They have taken the game and twisted it into something horrible .
I have been with this game from the start and every update has been worse then the previous.  Also every update has added more bugs which they will never fix.
Most of my play time has been through their launcher But you can see. I still have a decent amount of time shown through steam launcher.
If you play this game now and think it is enjoyable, Then there is something either seriously wrong with you or you have never played it before.
The game play itself has been destroyed. there are only 4 viable Weapon options now. You used to be able to have any weapon combo and be a viable bot . Not anymore most weapons have been changed to the point they are useless. Most things they still have in the game are pretty much useless now like shields, triforcing etc. you used to move up in level and have it mean something and have better bots and better weapons.
If you think that the game play will change as you go up in level  now,think again. It does not any longer.
The game play will be the same from start level 1-level 150. It means nothing.
I tell you this Most Vets of the Game like myself are gone. We refuse to play anymore. the Game has become that bad.
It used to be fun it used to be a challenge it used to be about teamwork and strategy. Now it is about kill stealing and rushing in to do as much damage as you can before being killed.
The crates and everything done in these last updates have been a disgrace to everything in the Gaming world.
The Devs are just greedy and praying on the youth and the stupid.
Play if you still want too, But I urge you not to give them any real money.
Trust me when I say this if they don't keep giving out gimmicks every week the game will DIE.
Steam charts show higher peaks , but they are slowly becoming pre-update average, but here is what they really show and you should look at these numbers the non peak times show an all time low. there used to be a average of 3,000-4,000 now it is 2,000-2,500.
Sure the peak times make the lower average equal out to seem high.
but that is only because of the gimmicks. When they go so will the player base and then shortly after the game itself.
I say good riddance to Horrible developers. They took what was once a great concept  destroyed it and twisted the entire thing into a cash grab.
I Plead once again,
PLAY THE GAME IF YOU WANT,  JUST DONT GIVE THEM MONEY."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I normally don't write reviews for games but...

What happened to this game...? a year ago it was one of my favorite games but these recent updates just made the game fall apart... focusing on more premium things than ever before (I get that you have to have some support) but everywhere you look or turn it mentions premium or you need premium for this or that.

Now there are guns with rockets that lock on to you??? and machine guns with bullets that lock onto you... they completely nerfed the medic class which was one of my favorite parts of the game and now it is completely useless... why have a medic when your robot auto heals after taking no damage for a few seconds? Where is the strategy and teamwork of trying to survive in the deathmatch and make plans instead of rushing into battle, so many things have been changed for the worse. I have never seen a game change this much for the worse... ever. Just stay away from this game and don't waste your time honestly.

You are not missing anything

Below is my review of the game at this point. I have tried to remain as un-biased as possible with respect to the crash problem I mentioned earlier.

-------------------------------

Robocraft used to be a game about building robots and fighting to the death. It used to emphasize builder skill and fighting tactics like recognizing the weak points on your opponents robot.

Used to.

The game now heavily focus on a MOBA style game mode without minions where teams of 8-12 players capture towers across the map. reviewText:
Early Access Review

I try to be balanced and unemotional when reviewing games. When I first started playing robocraft, it was fantastic. There was good progression, each battle rewarded you in accordance with your performance, and you could be very creative with your builds.This was because you could buy whatever you needed either with in-game currency from good performance or with cash it the mood struck you. There was no pressure to buy, and premium was so inexpensive that I didn't blink an eye at paying for it each day I actually played Robocraft.
Then all that changed. Now the game is a diceroll. I have received top score protonium crates dozens of times only to be handed cosmetic and useless items. The items are just as useless to sell, and so unless the dice smile upon you, your performance and rank are meaningless and you remain stuck with the equipement you have. It is a testament to the crappiness of this update that most of the equipment on my robot predates the update. I haven't been able to get anything better.
Constant messages are released by the developper about how they're ensuring better quality items are dropped. They're clearly not trying very hard as the stream of sewage (green uncommon" items) continues. It is becoming hard to view this as anything other than a pay-to-win cash grab.
I'm trying to hang in there
date: but I'm nearly done with it.  If you're just discovering Robocraft now
recommended: I'm sorry to have to tell you that you missed something really great. It's gone now. I'd move on."

I am not the only one experiencing this issue, and as far as I can tell, reports go back as far as two to three weeks ago with no answer from the developers or staff in any thread other than Don't bump threads". Thank you for your continued support and patience and we apologize for any inconvenience this issue may have caused.

DanSupportJammer"

Below is my review of the game at this point. I have tried to remain as un-biased as possible with respect to the crash problem I mentioned earlier.

-------------------------------

Robocraft used to be a game about building robots and fighting to the death. It used to emphasize builder skill and fighting tactics like recognizing the weak points on your opponents robot.

Used to.

The game now heavily focus on a MOBA style game mode without minions where teams of 8-12 players capture towers across the map. Each tower captured increases their weapons effectiveness against capturing other towers and damaging the opposing team's main reactor. If your team captures all three towers

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After playing 100 hours of Robocraft, I do not recommend playing it in its current state as of right now.

As a relatively new player, I was excited about the prospect of getting random things with a random chance, as I thought it would mean I can get the formerly Mega weapons easier. I was very excited to put life into robot ideas I had and to even test them in battle against other player's ideas.

I was wrong.

Even after all the crates, despite being Protonium most of the time, I have only received a single Legendary, it wasn't even the one I wanted. To get the two I wanted, I have to recycle around ~80% of what I earned, still barely reaching the price tag as either the recycle rate is far too low, or the prices of modules are far too high.

As a result, I was never really able to create any of the robots I had originally wanted to make, and the only way to achieve that goal now, is to mindlessly gamble my way there.

The crate system is also, at this point in time, not very well implemented. It only gives crates depending on your position on the team, whether or not you lose. It's very random in the loot it gives and that alone ruins Robocraft for me. It's just too unpredictable, and very hard to get the specific modules you want, and you're forced to deal with that because it's just how the economy was changed. Oh how I wish I experienced the only economy with RP and GC.

As Reddit User visorakkal said cleverly, Freejam should change their salaries to a loot-based system and see how that works out. You no longer get a paycheck

reviewText:
Product received for free

Early Access Review

So I've played Robocraft since it came out, only around 261 hours, but would play a little here and there so I wouldn't spoil too much after they relased from Early Access. I will be uninstalling this game now.

You used to get currency from playing. You would spend said currenty to buy cubes/weapons/items to customize and build your vehicles. It was a very easy system and honestly I had very little complaints. You can't do this anymore.

There is no currency now. You cannot buy cubes/weapons/items anymore. You can buy 'Loot Crates' or win crates from playing. What do you get when you open these crates? Random cubes/weapons/items. Random. Stuff.

So I can't just build what I want now. I can't simply buy the cubes I need. No, now I have to play with what I 'unlock' from these random loot boxes.

I am lucky enough that I have a couple of vehicles built from before this last 'Loot Box Update'. This is not the game I want to play and it IS NOT the game I started playing.

I do not recommend playing this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Many people have said the new gamemode ruined the game as a whole as it encourages no teamwork. But I beg to differ: sure during the early game, everyone is trying to shoot each other with only five second respawns - which is quite understandable - but when you get to the higher OC level, respawns are longer making players think about their actions as much as if they were just in the old gamemode. And the towers serve as a pivot to where you launch attacks from and use them strategically to get in a wave of spawns and vice versa preventing the enemy from spawning in for as long as possibe.

The shields definitely was a different mechanic where it endorses players to take the towers to stop the enemy from retreating and to prevent protonium bombing due to the enemy having a distinct advantage due to heals and short respawn times in the early game.

Now for my opinion. This game is, as what I learned, quite an addicting game giving the player to explore the giant possibilities of creating what ever the heck they want, and eventualy find their niche on what type of vehicle they like the most; I prefer heavy bombers. And that is what makes games fun.

And the balance is very methodical as the tier system dictates what type of things you could have at a given time within the rank. You could have powerful weapons, but sacrafice getting one shotted due to you having to use T1 blocks in a T3 environment. And that gives the player the freedom to go to what tiers they want to play in when reaching a higher rank. Of course you cannont immediately jump in and reach TX-1 due to level caps and grinding.

When you start everything is, technically, available to you needing tech points to unlock. But there isn't a mean of buying" tech points or cash as the devs have done an amazing job keeping it that way
date: and the only thing you can buy are pure cosmetics or pre-built bots. So everyone is on the same boat.\n\nAnd you can still play the old gamemode
recommended: by the way.\n\nEdit: After playing in the T1s
hoursPlayed: I can see why. Have no worry
voteText: because you get shields and towers in the later tiers."
